title: Weak coloring numbers of minor-closed graph classes

sections.text:
#### Abstract

We study the growth rate of weak coloring numbers of graphs excluding a fixed graph as a minor. Van den Heuvel et al. (European J. of Combinatorics, 2017) showed that for a fixed graph $X$, the maximum $r$-th weak coloring number of $X$-minor-free graphs is polynomial in $r$. We determine this polynomial up to a factor of $\mathcal{O}(r \log r)$. Moreover, we tie the exponent of the polynomial to a structural property of $X$, namely, 2 -treedepth. As a result, for a fixed graph $X$ and an $X$-minor-free graph $G$, we show that $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G)=\mathcal{O}\left(r^{\operatorname{ld}(X)-1} \log r\right)$, which improves on the bound $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G)=\mathcal{O}\left(r^{g(\operatorname{ld}(X))}\right)$ given by Dujmović et al. (SODA, 2024), where $g$ is an exponential function. In the case of planar graphs of bounded treewidth, we show that the maximum $r$-th weak coloring number is in $\mathcal{O}\left(r^{2} \log r\right)$, which is best possible.

# 1. INTRODUCTION 

Let $G$ be a graph, let $\Pi(G)$ be the set of all vertex orderings of $G$, let $\sigma \in \Pi(G)$, and let $r$ be a nonnegative integer. For all $u$ and $v$ vertices of $G$, we say that $v$ is weakly $r$-reachable from $u$ in $(G, \sigma)$, if there exists a path between $u$ and $v$ in $G$ containing at most $r$ edges such that for every vertex $w$ on the path, $v \leqslant_{\sigma} w$. Let $\mathrm{WReach}_{r}[G, \sigma, u]$ be the set of vertices that are weakly $r$-reachable from $u$ in $(G, \sigma)$. The $r$-th weak coloring number of $G$ is defined as

$$
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G)=\min _{\sigma \in \Pi(G)} \max _{u \in V(G)} \mid \mathrm{WReach}_{r}[G, \sigma, u] \mid
$$

Let $X$ be a graph. The treedepth of $X$, denoted by $\operatorname{td}(X)$, is defined recursively as follows

$$
\operatorname{td}(X)= \begin{cases}0 & \text { if } X \text { is the null graph } \\ \min _{v \in V(X)} \operatorname{td}(X-v)+1 & \text { if } X \text { is connected } \\ \max _{i \in[k]} \operatorname{td}\left(C_{i}\right) & \text { if } X \text { consists of components } C_{1}, \ldots, C_{k} \text { and } k>1\end{cases}
$$

The following two theorems are among the main contributions of this paper.
Theorem 1. For every positive integer $t$, for every graph $X$ with $\operatorname{td}(X) \leqslant t$, there exists an integer $c$ such that for every graph $G$, if $G$ is $X$-minor-free, then for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$,

$$
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G) \leqslant c \cdot r^{t-1} \log r
$$

Theorem 2. For every integer $t$ with $t \geqslant 2$, for every graph $X$ with $\operatorname{td}(X) \leqslant t$, there exists an integer $c$ such that for every graph $G$, if $G$ is $X$-minor-free, then for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$,

$$
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G) \leqslant c \cdot(\operatorname{tw}(G)+1) \cdot r^{t-2} \log r
$$

Weak coloring numbers were introduced by Kierstead and Yang [14] in 2003, though a parameter similar to $\operatorname{wcol}_{2}(G)$ is already present in the work of Chen and Schelp [1] from 1993. This family of parameters gained considerable attention when Zhu [21] proved that it captures important and robust notions of sparsity, namely, bounded expansion and nowhere denseness. Specifically, a class of graphs $\mathcal{C}$ has bounded expansion if and only if there exists a function $g$ such that for every graph $G$ in $\mathcal{C}$ and every positive integer $r$, we have $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G) \leqslant g(r)$. Classes of bounded expansion include in particular, planar graphs, graphs of bounded treewidth, and proper minor-closed graph classes; see the book by Nešetřil and Ossona de Mendez [15] or the recent lecture notes of Pilipczuk, Pilipczuk, and Siebertz [16] for more information on this topic. Many algorithmic problems were solved using the weak coloring numbers characterization of sparse graphs. Dvořák showed a constant-factor approximation for distance versions of domination number and independence number [4], with further applications in fixed-parameter algorithms and kernelization by Eickmeyer, Giannopoulou, Kreutzer, Kwon, Pilipczuk, Rabinovich, and Siebertz [5]. Grohe, Kreutzer, and Siebertz proved that deciding first-order properties is fixed-parameter tractable in nowhere dense graph classes [9]. Reidl and Sullivan presented an algorithm counting the number of occurrences of a fixed induced subgraph in sparse graphs [18]. The time complexities of all these algorithms depend heavily on the asymptotics of $\mathrm{wcol}_{r}$ in respective classes of graphs.

The growth rate of $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G)$ when $G$ is in a fixed proper minor-closed class of graphs has been extensively studied. In particular, Grohe, Kreutzer, Rabinovich, Siebertz, and Stavropoulos [8]

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ In this paper, connected graphs are nonnull, that is, they have at least one vertex. Note that a tree is defined as a connected forest, thus, trees and subtrees are also assumed to be nonnull.

proved that if $\operatorname{tw}(G) \leqslant t^{2}$, then $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G) \leqslant\binom{r+t}{t}$. This is tight as for all nonnegative integers $r, t$ they constructed a graph $G_{r, t}$ with $\operatorname{tw}\left(G_{r, t}\right)=t$ and $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G_{r, t}\right)=\binom{r+t}{t}^{3}$. In the class of planar graphs, $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G)=\mathcal{O}\left(r^{3}\right)$ as proved by van den Heuvel, Ossona de Mendez, Quiroz, Rabinovich, and Siebertz [11]. On the other hand, for the family of stacked triangulations (i.e. planar graphs of treewidth at most 3), we have $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G)=\Omega\left(r^{2} \log r\right)$, as shown by Joret and Micek [13]. The exact growth rate of maximum $r$-th weak coloring numbers of planar graphs is unknown. Theorem 2 immediately implies that in the class of planar graphs (or graphs of bounded Euler genus) of bounded treewidth, we have $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G)=\mathcal{O}\left(r^{2} \log r\right)$, which is tight. Indeed, it follows from Euler's formula that graphs of Euler genus at most $g$ exclude $K_{3,2 g+3}$ as a minor and $\operatorname{td}\left(K_{3,2 g+3}\right)=4$ for all nonnegative integers $g$.

Corollary 3. For all nonnegative integers $g, w$, there exists an integer $c$ such that for every graph $G$ of Euler genus at most $g$ and with $\operatorname{tw}(G) \leqslant w$, and for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$,

$$
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G) \leqslant c \cdot r^{2} \log r
$$

Since outerplanar graphs are $K_{2,3}$-minor-free and have bounded treewidth, Theorem 2 yields that $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G)=\mathcal{O}(r \log r)$ in the class of outerplanar graphs $G$. This was already proved by Joret and Micek [13], who additionally showed that this bound is tight.

More generally, fix a graph $X$. What is the growth rate with respect to $r$ of the maximum of $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G)$ for all $X$-minor-free graphs $G$ ? Van den Heuvel et al. [11] showed that $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G)=\mathcal{O}\left(r^{|V(X)|-1}\right)$. Subsequently, van den Heuvel and Wood [10] proved that $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G)=\mathcal{O}\left(r^{\mathrm{xc}(X)+1}\right)$. Dujmović, Hickingbotham, Hodor, Joret, La, Micek, Morin, Rambaud, and Wood [2] proved that there exists an exponential function $g$ such that $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G)=$ $\mathcal{O}\left(r^{g(\operatorname{td}(X))}\right)$. We directly improve this result, namely, Theorem 1 states that $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G)=$ $\mathcal{O}\left(r^{\operatorname{td}(X)-1} \log r\right)$ and Theorem 2 states that $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G)=\mathcal{O}\left(\operatorname{tw}(G) \cdot r^{\operatorname{td}(X)-2} \log r\right)$. Moreover, since $\operatorname{td}(X)-1 \leqslant \operatorname{vc}(G)$, we obtain $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G)=\mathcal{O}\left(r^{\operatorname{vc}(X)} \log r\right)$ and $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G)=$ $\mathcal{O}\left(\operatorname{tw}(G) \cdot r^{\mathrm{xc}(X)-1} \log r\right)$. In these cases, the construction of Grohe et al. [8] witnesses that our bounds are tight up to a factor of $\mathcal{O}(r \log r)$ in the general case and up to $\mathcal{O}(\log r)$ in the case of bounded treewidth. Most of the known bounds on weak coloring numbers of minor-closed graph classes are summarized in Table 1.

All this previous work can be seen as an effort to understand the following graph parameter. For a given graph $X$, let

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(X)=\inf \{\alpha \in \mathbb{R} \mid & \text { there exists } c>0 \text { such that for every } X \text {-minor-free graph } G \\
& \text { and for every nonnegative integer } r, \operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G) \leqslant c \cdot r^{\alpha}\}
\end{aligned}
$$

The question is whether $f$ is tied to ${ }^{4}$ some other well-established graph parameters. Recall that for every graph $X$,

$$
\operatorname{tw}(X) \leqslant \operatorname{pw}(X) \leqslant \operatorname{td}(X)-1 \leqslant \operatorname{vc}(X) \leqslant|V(X)|-1
$$

The aforementioned results imply that $\operatorname{tw}(X)-1 \leqslant f(X) \leqslant \operatorname{td}(X)-1$. However, $f$ is not tied to any of these parameters. Indeed, neither pathwidth nor treedepth can lower bound $f$. For every positive integer $k$, let $T_{k}$ be a complete ternary tree of vertex-height $k$. Recall that there is a constant depending on $k$ bounding pathwidth of $T_{k}$-minor-free graphs by Robertson-Seymour

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{2}$ For a graph $G$, let $\operatorname{tw}(G), \operatorname{pw}(G)$, and $\operatorname{vc}(G)$ stand for the treewidth, pathwidth, and vertex cover number of $G$ respectively.
    ${ }^{3}$ We recall the construction in Section 2.1.
    ${ }^{4}$ Two graph parameters $p, q$ are said to be tied if there are two functions $\alpha, \beta$ such that $p(G) \leqslant \alpha(q(G))$ and $q(G) \leqslant \beta(p(G))$ for every graph $G$.

Excluded Tree Minor Theorem [19]. Also, it is easy to show ${ }^{5}$ that $\mathrm{wcol}_{r}(G) \leqslant 1+\mathrm{pw}(G)(2 r+1)$ for every graph $G$. Thus, $f\left(T_{k}\right) \leqslant 1$ while $\operatorname{pw}\left(T_{k}\right)=k$ and $\operatorname{td}\left(T_{k}\right)=k+1$. Next, we argue that neither treewidth nor pathwidth can upper-bound $f$. For every positive integer $k$, let $L_{k}$ be a ladder with $k$ rungs. There is a graph $G_{r, t}$ (constructed in [8]) such that $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G_{r, t}\right)=$ $\Omega\left(r^{t}\right)$, and if $k=\Omega(\log t)$, then $G_{r, t}$ excludes $L_{k}$ as a minor. Therefore, $f\left(L_{k}\right)=2^{\Omega(k)}$, and $\operatorname{tw}\left(L_{k}\right) \leqslant \operatorname{pw}\left(L_{k}\right) \leqslant 2$.

Surprisingly, the key parameter to our problem is 2 -treedepth as defined by Huynh, Joret, Micek, Seweryn, and Wollan in [12], where they use it to characterize the structure of graphs excluding a fixed ladder as a minor. Let $X$ be a graph. A cut vertex of $X$ is a vertex $v \in V(X)$ such that $X-v$ has more components than $X$. A block of $X$ is a maximal connected subgraph of $X$ without a cut vertex. ${ }^{6}$ The 2 -treedepth of $X$, denoted by $\operatorname{td}_{2}(X)$, is defined recursively as follows

$$
\operatorname{td}_{2}(X)= \begin{cases}0 & \text { if } X \text { is the null graph } \\ \min _{v \in V(X)} \operatorname{td}_{2}(X-v)+1 & \text { if } X \text { consists of one block, and } \\ \max _{i \in[k]} \operatorname{td}_{2}\left(B_{i}\right) & \text { if } X \text { consists of blocks } B_{1}, \ldots, B_{k} \text { and } k>1\end{cases}
$$

We show that $f$ is tied by a linear function to $\operatorname{td}_{2}$. The first inequality in the theorem below is witnessed by the construction given in [8].

Theorem 4. For every graph $X$ with at least one edge, we have

$$
\operatorname{td}_{2}(X)-2 \leqslant f(X) \leqslant 2 \operatorname{td}_{2}(X)-3
$$

To prove Theorems 1 and 4, we prove that the value of $f$ is tied with the maximum $t$ such that $X$ is a subgraph of $G_{r, t}$ (as in [8]). In other words, we prove that $G_{r, t}$ is the obstruction for the growth of weak coloring numbers. More precisely, we introduce a slightly modified version of 2 -treedepth, which we call rooted 2 -treedepth and denote by $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(\cdot)$. Later, we show that for all graphs $X$ with at least one edge, $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X)$ is the minimum $t$ such that there exists $r$ such that $X$ is a subgraph of $G_{r, t-1}$. See Section 4 for the definition of rooted 2 -treedepth and Lemma 26 for the equivalence.

Given a graph $X$ with at least one edge, we will show that $\operatorname{td}_{2}(X) \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X) \leqslant 2 \operatorname{td}_{2}(X)-2$ and it will be clear from the definition that $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X) \leqslant \operatorname{td}(X)$. As a consequence, Theorems 1 and 4 are implied by the following more accurate technical statement. See also Figure 1.

Theorem 5. For every positive integer $t$, for every graph $X$ with $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X) \leqslant t$, there exists an integer $c$ such that for every graph $G$, if $G$ is $X$-minor-free, then for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$,

$$
\mathrm{wcol}_{r}(G) \leqslant c \cdot r^{t-1} \log r
$$

Moreover, for all nonnegative integers $r, t$, the graph $G_{r, t}$ of [8] satisfies $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(G_{r, t}\right)=t+1$ and $\mathrm{wcol}_{r}\left(G_{r, t}\right)=\Omega\left(r^{t}\right)$. Since rooted 2 -treedepth is minor-monotone ${ }^{7}$ (see Lemma 22), for

If $\mathrm{pw}(G)>0$, let $Q$ be a shortest path from the first bag to the last bag of an optimal path decomposition of $G$. Then $\operatorname{pw}(G-V(Q))<\operatorname{pw}(G)$ and so by induction $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G-V(Q)) \leqslant$ $1+(\operatorname{pw}(G)-1)(2 r+1)$. Let $\sigma_{0}$ be an ordering of $V(G)$ witnessing this fact. Now, let $\sigma$ be an ordering of $V(G)$ extending $\sigma_{0}$ such that the vertices in $V(Q)$ appear first. By Lemma 9, it follows that $\sigma$ witnesses $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G) \leqslant 1+(\operatorname{pw}(G)-1)(2 r+1)+(2 r+1)=1+\operatorname{pw}(G)(2 r+1)$.

Table 1. Lower and upper bounds on $\max _{G \in \mathcal{C}} \mathrm{wcol}_{r}(G)$ for some minorclosed graphs classes $\mathcal{C}$. The variables $g, k, s, t$ are fixed positive integers with $s+3 \leqslant t \leqslant k$, and $X$ is a fixed nonnull graph. The weak coloring numbers of $K_{s, t}$-minor-free graphs were first studied by van den Heuvel and Wood in [10]. In particular they proved the upper bound $\mathcal{O}\left(r^{s+1}\right)$ and they conjectured $\mathcal{O}\left(r^{s}\right)$. Theorem 1 implies that $K_{s, t}$-minor-free graphs have weak coloring numbers in $\mathcal{O}\left(r^{s} \log r\right)$. The lower bound $\Omega\left(r^{s-1} \log r\right)$ follows from the fact that graphs of simple treewidth $s$ are $K_{s, t}$-minor-free and among them there are graphs with weak coloring numbers in $\Omega\left(r^{s-1} \log r\right)$, see [13] for further details.
every graph $X$ with at least one edge, $G_{r, \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X)-2}$ is $X$-minor-free and $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G_{r, \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X)-2}\right)=$ $\Omega\left(r^{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X)-2}\right)$ for every positive integer $r$. This and Theorem 5 imply that for every graph $X$ with at least one edge,

$$
\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X)-2 \leqslant f(X) \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X)-1
$$

Similarly, Theorem 2 is a direct consequence of the following technical statement.
Theorem 6. For every integer $t$ with $t \geqslant 2$, for every graph $X$ with $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X) \leqslant t$, there exists an integer $c$ such that for every graph $G$, if $G$ is $X$-minor-free, then for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$,

$$
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G) \leqslant c \cdot(\operatorname{tw}(G)+1) \cdot r^{t-2} \log r
$$

![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Figure 1. Connections of $f$ to other graph parameters. An arrow from a parameter $p$ to a parameter $q$ indicates that there is a function $\alpha$ such that $p(X) \leqslant \alpha(q(X))$ for every graph $X$. We show that $f$ is tied to $\mathrm{td}_{2}$ and $\mathrm{rtd}_{2}$ but not to tw, pw, td, vc, or $|V|$. The results marked in the figure (top-to-bottom) are in [11], [10], [2], and [8] respectively.

When $X$ is a planar graph, $X$-minor-free graphs have bounded treewidth by the Grid-Minor Theorem [20]. Hence, Theorem 6 implies that for every planar graph $X$ with at least one edge,

$$
f(X)=\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X)-2
$$

We conclude the introduction with our two favorite problems in the area.
Question 1. What is the asymptotic of the maximum of $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G)$ when G is planar? As discussed, it is known to be $\Omega\left(r^{2} \log r\right)$ and $\mathcal{O}\left(r^{3}\right)$. In this paper, we show that the lower bound is tight for planar graphs of bounded treewidth.

For a positive integer $p$, a vertex coloring $\phi$ of a graph $G$ is $p$-centered if for every connected subgraph $H$ of $G$, either $\phi$ uses more than $p$ colors in $V(H)$ or there is a color that appears exactly once in $H$. The $p$-centered chromatic number of $G$, denoted by $\chi_{p}(G)$, is the least number of colors in a $p$-centered coloring of $G$. Centered colorings are tied with weak coloring numbers and therefore they also characterize classes of bounded expansion. However, we seemingly miss the right proof technique to get upper bounds on $\chi_{p}(G)$ when $G$ excludes a fixed graph as a minor.

Question 2. Is there a function $g$ such that for every fixed graph $X$, for every $X$-minor-free graph $G$ and for every positive integer $p$,

$$
\chi_{p}(G)=\mathcal{O}\left(p^{g(\operatorname{td}(X))}\right) ?
$$

All we know is that $\chi_{p}(G)=\mathcal{O}\left(p^{g(|V(X)|)}\right)$ for some function $g$ as proved by Pilipczuk and Siebertz in [17].

sections.text:
# 2. OUTLINE OF THE PROOFS 

In this section, we introduce several notions that we use in the proofs of Theorem 5 and Theorem 6 and then we sketch their proofs.

First, we establish basic notation. For a positive integer $k$, we write $[k]=\{1, \ldots, k\}$ and $[0]=\emptyset$. The null graph is the graph with no vertices. All graphs considered in this paper are

finite, simple, and undirected. Let $G_{1}, G_{2}$ be two graphs. We denote by $G_{1} \sqcup G_{2}$ the disjoint union of $G_{1}$ and $G_{2}$, and by $G_{1} \oplus G_{2}$ the graph obtained from $G_{1} \sqcup G_{2}$ by adding every edge with one endpoint in $V\left(G_{1}\right)$ and the other in $V\left(G_{2}\right)$. For every positive integer $k$, for every graph $G$, we write $k \cdot G$ for the union of $k$ disjoint copies of $G$.
2.1. The key parameter. Let $G$ be a graph and let $k$ be a nonnegative integer. A separation of order $k$ of $G$ is a pair $(A, B)$ of subgraphs of $G$ such that ${ }^{0} A \cup B=G, E(A \cap B)=\emptyset$, and $|V(A \cap B)|=k$. We define recursively a new graph parameter called rooted 2 -treedepth, denoted by $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}$, as follows. For every graph $G$,
(r1) $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)=0$ if $G$ is the null graph,
(r2) $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)=1$ if $G$ is a one vertex graph, and otherwise
(r3) $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)$ is the minimum of $\max \left\{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(A), \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-V(A))+|V(A) \cap V(B)|\right\}$ over all separations $(A, B)$ of $G$ of order at most one with $V(A) \neq \emptyset$ and $V(B)-V(A) \neq \emptyset$.

Another way to understand $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}$ is through "natural" separations of the graph defined by its block decomposition. When $G$ is not connected, $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)$ is realized by $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(C)$, where $C$ is a component of $G$ for which the value of $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}$ is the greatest. When $G$ consists of a single block, a separation $(A, B)$ of $G$ with $V(A) \neq \emptyset$ and $V(B)-V(A) \neq \emptyset$ of order at most one is such that $V(A)=\{v\}$ and $B=G$. Therefore, $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)=\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G-v)+1$. When $G$ consists of multiple blocks, the minimum of $\max \left\{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(A), \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-V(A))+|V(A) \cap V(B)|\right\}$ is reached for separations where $V(A) \cap V(B)$ consists of exactly one cut-vertex of $G$. The above can be summarized as the following properties. For every graph $G$,
(r4) $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)$ is the maximum of $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(C)$ over all components $C$ of $G$ when $G$ is not connected,
(r5) $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)$ is the minimum of $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G-v)+1$ over all vertices $v$ of $G$ when $G$ consists of one block,
(r6) $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)$ is the minimum of $\max \left\{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(A), \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-V(A))+1\right\}$ over all separations $(A, B)$ of $G$ of order one with $V(A) \cap V(B)$ consisting of a cut-vertex, when $G$ is connected and consists of more than one block.

Moreover, observe that $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G) \leqslant \max \left\{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(A), \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-V(A))+|V(A) \cap V(B)|\right\}$ for every separation $(A, B)$ of $G$ of order at most one. In particular, for every $u \in V(G),(G[\{u\}], G)$ is a separation of $G$ of order one, and so,
(r7) $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G) \leqslant 1+\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G-u)$.
Finally, vertices of degree 1 can not increase rooted 2 -treedepth of a graph.
(r8) $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G) \leqslant \max \left\{2, \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G-u)\right\}$ for every $u \in V(G)$ of degree at most 1.

Rooted 2-treedepth has several interesting properties: it is minor-monotone, see Lemma 22; and it is also tied to 2 -treedepth. More precisely, for every graph $G$, we have $\operatorname{td}_{2}(G) \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G) \leqslant$ $\max \left\{1,2 \operatorname{td}_{2}(G)-2\right\}$ - see Lemma 23, and these inequalities are tight - see Lemma 25.

The parameter $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}$ originates from a construction by Grohe et al. [8] of graphs $G_{r, t}$ for all nonnegative integers $r$ and $t$ such that

$$
\operatorname{tw}\left(G_{r, t}\right)=t \quad \text { and } \quad \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G_{r, t}\right)=\binom{r+t}{t}
$$

We now recall this construction. Let $d$ be a positive integer, let $B$ and $H$ be two graphs, and let $u$ be a vertex of $H$. We define $L_{d}(B, H, u)$ as the graph obtained in the following process.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{0}$ For all graphs $A, B$, let $A \cup B=(V(A) \cup V(B), E(A) \cup E(B))$ and $A \cap B=(V(A) \cap V(B), E(A) \cap E(B))$.

![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

Figure 2. An construction of $L_{2}(B, H, u)$, where $B$ is a triangle and $H$ is a path on three vertices with $u$ being one of its endpoints.

Take a copy of $B$ and $d|V(B)|$ copies of $H$. Label the latter $H_{i, x}$ for each $i \in[d]$ and $x \in V(B)$. Next, for each $x \in V(B)$ identify $x$ and $u$ in each $H_{i, x}$ for $i \in[d]$. See Figure 2.

For all nonnegative integers $r, t$ the graph $G_{r, t}$ is defined recursively for all nonnegative integers $r$ and $t$ by

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
G_{0, t}=G_{r, 0}=K_{1} \\
G_{r, t}=L_{\binom{r+t}{i}}\left(G_{r-1, t}, K_{1} \oplus G_{r, t-1}, u\right) \text { if } r, t>0
\end{array}\right.
$$

where $u$ is the vertex of $K_{1}$ in $K_{1} \oplus G_{r, t-1}$. Observe that $G_{r, 1}$ is a tree for all nonnegative integers $r$.

One can show that for all nonnegative integers $r, t$ and positive integer $d$,

$$
\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(L_{d}\left(G_{r-1, t}, K_{1} \oplus G_{r, t-1}, u\right)\right) \leqslant \max \left\{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(G_{r-1, t}\right), 1+\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(G_{r, t-1}\right)\right\}
$$

Therefore, by induction, $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(G_{r, t}\right)=t+1$. In fact, this construction is universal for graphs of rooted 2 -treedepth at most $t+1$ (see Lemma 26). Namely, for every graph $G, \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G) \leqslant t+1$ if and only if $G$ is isomorphic to a subgraph of $G_{r, t}$ for some nonnegative integer $r$. Since rooted 2 -treedepth is minor-monotone, we deduce that for every graph $X, G_{r, \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X)-2}$ is $X$ -minor-free. It follows that there are $X$-minor-free graphs with $r$-th weak coloring numbers in $\Omega\left(r^{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X)-2}\right)$. Hence, Theorem 5 yields that for every nonnegative integer $t$, if a minor-closed class of graphs contains graphs with $r$-th weak coloring in $\omega\left(r^{t} \log r\right)$, then it contains $G_{r, t}$ for every nonnegative integer $r$. As a consequence, in the setting of minor-closed graphs classes, our results imply that the family constructed by Grohe et al. is, up to an $\mathcal{O}(r \log r)$ factor, the unique construction of graphs with large weak coloring numbers. Similarly, in the setting of minor-closed graphs classes of bounded treewidth, the family constructed by Grohe et al. is, up to an $\mathcal{O}(\log r)$ factor, the unique construction of graphs with large weak coloring numbers.
2.2. Weak coloring numbers of $(G, S)$. Another key ingredient in our method is a notion of weak coloring numbers focused on a given subset $S$ of vertices of a graph $G$. Intuitively, we want to order the vertices of $S$ and place them first in the ordering of $V(G)$ so that, whatever the ordering of the other vertices is, every vertex weakly reaches a small number of vertices in $S$.

Let $G$ be a graph, let $r$ be a nonnegative integer, let $S \subseteq V(G)$, let $\sigma$ be an ordering of $S$, let $u \in V(G)$, and let $v \in S$. We say that $v$ is weakly $r$-reachable from $u$ in $(G, S, \sigma)$ if there is an $u-v$ path $P$ in $G$ of length at most $r$ such that $\min _{\sigma}(V(P) \cap S)=v$. We denote by $\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u]$ the set of all the weakly $r$-reachable vertices from $u$ in $(G, S, \sigma)$ and we write $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S, \sigma)=\max _{u \in V(G)}\left|\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u]\right|$. Finally, let $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S)$ be the minimum value of $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S, \sigma)$ among all $\sigma$ orderings of $S$. For each of the defined objects, we drop $S$ when $S=V(G)$. Namely, $v$ is weakly $r$-reachable from $u$ in $(G, \sigma)$ whenever $v$ is weakly $r$-reachable from $u$ in $(G, V(G), \sigma)$, $\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, \sigma, u]=\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, V(G), \sigma, u]$,

![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)

Figure 3. The pink vertices correspond to the set $S$. The vertices in $S$ highlighted blue are in $\mathrm{WReach}_{3}[G, S, \sigma, u]$.
$\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, \sigma)=\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, V(G), \sigma)$, and $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G)=\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, V(G))$. This matches the definition given in Section 1. See an illustration in Figure 3. In Section 3, we give many properties of this notion.
2.3. $\mathcal{F}$-rich models. For a graph $H$, a model of $H$ in a graph $G$ is a family $\left(B_{x} \mid x \in V(H)\right)$ of disjoint subsets of $V(G)$ such that
(i) $G\left[B_{x}\right]$ is connected, for every $x \in V(H)$; and
(ii) there is an edge between $B_{x}$ and $B_{y}$ in $G$, for every $x y \in E(H)$.

If $G$ has a model of $H$, then we say that $H$ is a minor of $G$. Let $\mathcal{F}$ be a family of connected subgraphs of $G$. Such a model of $H$ is said to be $\mathcal{F}$-rich if we have the additional following property.
(iii) For every $x \in V(H)$, there exists $F \in \mathcal{F}$ such that $F \subseteq G\left[B_{x}\right]$.

For example, if $H$ has $k$ vertices and no edges, then $G$ has an $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $H$ if and only if $G$ contains $k$ pairwise disjoint members of $\mathcal{F}$. Another extreme case is when $\mathcal{F}$ contains every one-vertex subgraph of $G$. Then every model of $H$ in $G$ is $\mathcal{F}$-rich.
2.4. Plan of the proof. We now present the main ideas behind the proofs of Theorem 5 and Theorem 6. In order to prove the theorems, we strengthen the statement and instead of considering graphs with no models of $X$, we consider graphs with no $\mathcal{F}$-rich models of $X$, given a family $\mathcal{F}$ of connected subgraphs of $G$. This turns out to be very helpful in keeping induction invariant if we carefully choose $\mathcal{F}$. For some choices of $\mathcal{F}$, excluding an $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of a graph may be a local property. Therefore, we keep a global property that $G$ excludes $K_{k}$ as a minor, where $k=|V(X)|$. The locality of the property suggests that the bound on weak coloring numbers should be local in some sense as well. To this end, instead of bounding $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G)$, we bound $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S)$, where $S$ is a hitting set for $\mathcal{F}$, that is $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$. A result in this spirit, that corresponds to excluding every $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of an edgeless graph $X$, is already present in [2]. We restate this result below with adjusted notations (see Lemma 18 for the original statement).

Lemma 7. There exists a function $\delta$ such that for all positive integers $k, d$, for every connected $K_{k}$-minor-free graph $G$, for every family $\mathcal{F}$ of connected subgraphs of $G$, if there are no d pairwise vertex-disjoint subgraphs in $\mathcal{F}$, then there exists $S \subseteq V(G)$ such that
(a) $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$;
(b) $G[S]$ is connected;
(c) $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) \leqslant \delta(k, d) \cdot r$ for every positive integer $r$.

Pushing this idea further, we show the following technical version of Theorem 5, which can be seen as the induction setup.

![img-3.jpeg](img-3.jpeg)

Figure 4. On the left-hand side, we depict an $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $X$, where $X$ is a cycle on 8 vertices and $\mathcal{F}$ is the family of all connected subgraphs of $G-\{u\}$ containing a neighbor of $u$ in $G$. On the right-hand side, we show how to construct, given an $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $X$, a model of $K_{1} \oplus X$.

Theorem 8. Let $k$ and $t$ be positive integers with $t \geqslant 2$. Let $X$ be a graph with $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X) \leqslant t$. There exists an integer $c(t, X, k)$ such that for every connected $K_{k}$-minor-free graph $G$, for every family $\mathcal{F}$ of connected subgraphs of $G$, if $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $X$, then there exists $S \subseteq V(G)$ such that
(A) $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$;
(B) $G[S]$ is connected;
(C) $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) \leqslant c(t, X, k) \cdot r^{t-1} \log r$ for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$.

To recover Theorem 5 from this last statement, apply it for a family $\mathcal{F}$ containing each onevertex subgraph of $G$. Then (A) implies that $S=V(G)$, and so, $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G)=\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) \leqslant$ $c(t, X, k) \cdot r^{t-1} \log r$ by (C). The assumption that $G$ is $K_{k}$-minor-free is necessary: for every positive integer $n$, if $\mathcal{F}$ is the family of all the subgraphs of $K_{n}$ with more than $\frac{n}{2}$ vertices, then $K_{n}$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $K_{2}$, but every hitting set $S$ of $\mathcal{F}$ satisfies $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) \geqslant \frac{n}{2}$ for every nonnegative integer $r$, which is not bounded by a function of $r$. Item (B) is a technical condition that supports the induction.

The proof of Theorem 8 is by induction on $t$. Within the inductive step, given the result for all $X$ with $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X)=t-1$ we argue that the result holds for graphs of rooted 2 -treedepth equal $t$. First, we prove it for graphs of the form $K_{1} \oplus X$ where $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X)=t-1$. Let $G$ be a $K_{1} \oplus X$-minor-free graph. Let $u$ be a vertex of $G$ and let $\mathcal{F}$ be the family of all the connected subgraphs $H$ of $G-\{u\}$ that contain a neighbor of $u$ in $G$. Then observe that any $\mathcal{F}$-rich model $\left(B_{x} \mid x \in V(X)\right)$ of $X$ in $G-\{u\}$ yields a model $\left(C_{x} \mid x \in V(X) \cup\{s\}\right)$ of $K_{1} \oplus X$ defined by $C_{x}=B_{x}$ for every $x \in V(X)$ and $C_{s}=\{u\}$ - see Figure 4. Therefore, $G-\{u\}$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $X$. Hence, choosing $\mathcal{F}$ carefully, we can deduce that $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $X$ knowing that $G$ has no model of $K_{1} \oplus X$. This technique will allow us to prove Theorem 8 for $K_{1} \oplus X$, assuming the result for $X$ (see Claim 1 and Claim 2 in the proof of Theorem 8). When we have the result for graphs of the form $K_{1} \oplus X$, we follow the inductive definition of rooted 2 -treedepth and conclude the full statement of Theorem 8, see Claim 3.

Here is the summary of the plan of the proof of Theorem 8, with the bounds on $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S)$ obtained at each step:

1. Pre-base case: $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X) \leqslant 1$, i.e. $X$ has no edges; Lemma 17.
$\mathcal{O}(r)$
2. Base case: $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X) \leqslant 2$, i.e. $X$ is a forest; Section 5.
a. $X$ is a star; Lemmas 30 and 31.
$\mathcal{O}(r \log r)$

b. $X$ is a forest; Lemma 33.
$\mathcal{O}(r \log r)$
3. Induction: $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X) \leqslant t$, assuming the result for $t-1$; Section 6 .
a. $X=K_{1} \oplus Y$ for some $Y$ with $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(Y) \leqslant t-1$; Claims 1 and 2.
b. $X$ is any graph with $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X) \leqslant t$; Claim 3.
$\mathcal{O}\left(r^{t-1} \log r\right)$
$\mathcal{O}\left(r^{t-1} \log r\right)$

The logarithmic factor appears already in the base case. This phenomenon can be explained as follows. Graphs excluding a fixed tree as a minor have bounded pathwidth [19], and it is known that paths have logarithmic weak coloring numbers (see [13] or Figure 10). Combining these ideas, one can show that graphs excluding a fixed tree as a minor have logarithmic weak coloring numbers. Here, we are working in the more general setting of graphs with no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of a fixed tree, and so we do not have bounded pathwidth. However, using a similar strategy together with Lemma 7, we prove in our base case an $\mathcal{O}(r \log r)$ bound for weak coloring numbers of a hitting set of $\mathcal{F}$, in a $K_{k}$-minor-free graphs with no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of a fixed tree.

The proof of Theorem 6 is very similar, except that a factor $\mathcal{O}(r)$ is saved in the first step. This comes from the fact that for every graph $G$, for every family $\mathcal{F}$ of connected subgraphs of $G$, if there are no $d+1$ disjoint members of $\mathcal{F}$, then there exists a hitting set $S \subseteq V(G)$ of $\mathcal{F}$ of size at most $d \cdot(\operatorname{tw}(G)+1)$. In particular, $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) \leqslant|S| \leqslant d \cdot(\operatorname{tw}(G)+1)$ for every nonnegative integer $r$. This fact (see Lemma 35) will replace Lemma 7 in the first step of the proof, which improves by a factor $\mathcal{O}(r)$ the bound obtained in the more general setting of $K_{k}$-minor-free graphs. In the proof of Theorem 5, for technical reasons we keep as an invariant that $G[S]$ is connected. The techniques used in the proof Theorem 6 force us to relax this condition slightly. Now, we assert that for every component $C$ of $G-S, N_{G}(V(C))$ intersects only few components of $G-V(C)$. This makes the proof slightly more technical. However, the main ideas are the same, and substantial parts of the proofs overlap.
2.5. Organisation of the paper. In Section 3, we introduce notation and some simple properties that will be used throughout the paper. In Section 4, we prove several properties of the rooted 2 -treedepth, and show its connection with the construction $\left\{G_{r, t}\right\}_{r, t \geqslant 0}[8]$. In Section 5, we prove the base case of Theorem 8 when $X$ is a forest. In Section 6, we prove Theorem 8. Finally, in Section 7, we prove Theorem 6 with the same method.

# 3. Preliminaries 

Let $G$ be a graph and let $A, B, Z \subseteq V(G)$. We say that $Z$ separates $A$ and $B$ in $G$ if no component of $G-Z$ intersects both $A$ and $B$.

A collection $\mathcal{P}$ of subsets of a non-empty set $S$ is a partition of $S$ if elements of $\mathcal{P}$ are nonempty, pairwise disjoint, and $\bigcup \mathcal{P}=S$. A sequence $\left(P_{0}, \ldots, P_{m}\right)$ of subsets of a set $S$ is an ordered partition of $S$ if $\left\{P_{i}\right\}_{i \in\{0, \ldots, m\}}$ is a partition of $S$. Given a graph $G$ and a partition $\mathcal{P}$ of $V(G)$, the quotient graph $G / \mathcal{P}$ is the graph with the vertex set $\mathcal{P}$ and two distinct $P, P^{\prime} \in \mathcal{P}$ are adjacent in $G / \mathcal{P}$ if there are $u \in P$ and $u^{\prime} \in P^{\prime}$ such that $u u^{\prime}$ is an edge in $G$.

A layering of a graph $G$ is an ordered partition $\left(P_{0}, \ldots, P_{\ell}\right)$ of $V(G)$ such that for every edge $u v$ in $G$ either there is $i \in\{0, \ldots, \ell\}$ with $u, v \in P_{i}$ or there is $i \in\{0, \ldots, \ell-1\}$ with $u \in P_{i}$ and $v \in P_{i+1}$. A tree partition of a graph $G$ is a pair $(T, \mathcal{P})$, where $T$ is a tree and $\mathcal{P}=\left(P_{x} \mid x \in V(T)\right)$ is a partition of $V(G)$ such that for every edge $u v$ in $G$ either there is $x \in V(T)$ with $u, v \in P_{x}$ or there is an edge $x y$ in $T$ with $u \in P_{x}$ and $v \in P_{y}$.

Let $G$ be a graph. For $X, Y \subseteq V(G)$, an $X-Y$ path is a path in $G$ that is either a one-vertex path with the vertex in $X \cap Y$ or a path with one endpoint in $X$ and the other endpoint in $Y$

such that no internal vertices are in $X \cup Y$. When $u, v \in V(G)$, instead of $\{u\} \cdot\{v\}$ path we write $u-v$ path for short. The length of a path $P$ is the number of edges of $P$. A path $P$ is a geodesic in $G$ if it is a shortest path between its endpoints in $G$. The distance between two vertices $u$ and $v$ in $G$, denoted by $\operatorname{dist}_{G}(u, v)$, is the length of a $u-v$ geodesic in $G$ when it exists, and $+\infty$ otherwise. Let $u$ be a vertex of $G$. The neighborhood of $u$ in $G$, denoted by $N_{G}(u)$, is the set $\{v \in V(G) \mid u v \in E(G)\}$. For every set of vertices $X$ of $G$, let $N_{G}(X)=\bigcup_{u \in X} N_{G}(u)-X$. For every positive integer $r$, we denote by $N_{G}^{r}[u]=\left\{v \in V(G) \mid \operatorname{dist}_{G}(u, v) \leqslant r\right\}$. The following lemma is folklore, see e.g. [2, Lemma 23] for a proof.

Lemma 9. Let $G$ be a graph and $r$ be a nonnegative integer. For every geodesic $Q$ in $G$ and for every vertex $v \in V(G)$,

$$
\left|N^{r}[v] \cap V(Q)\right| \leqslant 2 r+1
$$

An ordering $\sigma$ of a finite set $E$ is a sequence $\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{|E|}\right)$ of all the elements of $E$. For all $x, y \in E$, we write $x \leqslant_{\sigma} y$ when there are $i, j \in\|E\|$ such that $x_{i}=x, x_{j}=y$, and $i \leqslant j$. We also write $\min _{\sigma} E=x_{1}$ and $\max _{\sigma} E=x_{|E|}$. When $F \subseteq E$, we write $\left.\sigma\right|_{F}$ for the restriction of $\sigma$ to $F$ that is defined as the ordering of $F$ such that $x \leqslant_{\left.\sigma\right|_{F}} y$ if and only if $x \leqslant_{\sigma} y$ for all $x, y \in F$. For every nonempty $F \subseteq E$, we define $\min _{\sigma} F=\min _{\sigma \mid F} F$ and $\max _{\sigma} F=\max _{\sigma \mid F} F$. For all $F, F^{\prime} \subseteq E$, we write $F<_{\sigma} F^{\prime}$ whenever for all $x \in F$ and $y \in F^{\prime}$, we have $x<_{\sigma} y$. If $\sigma^{\prime}$ is an ordering of $F \subseteq E$, we say that $\sigma$ extends $\sigma^{\prime}$ if $\left.\sigma\right|_{F}=\sigma^{\prime}$.

When $H$ is a subgraph of a graph $G$ and $\mathcal{F}$ is a family of subgraphs of $G$, we denote by $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{H}$ the family $\{F \in \mathcal{F} \mid F \subseteq H\}$.

Next, we state a bunch of simple observations concerning the notion of weak coloring numbers in the version presented above.

Observation 10. Let $G$ be a graph and let $S \subseteq V(G)$. Let $G^{\prime}$ consist of all the components of $G$ that contain a vertex from $S$. For every nonnegative integer $r$, we have

$$
\mathrm{wcol}_{r}(G, S)=\mathrm{wcol}_{r}\left(G^{\prime}, S\right)
$$

Observation 11. Let $G$ be a graph, $S \subseteq V(G)$, and $\mathcal{C}$ be the family of components of $G$. For every nonnegative integer $r$, we have

$$
\mathrm{wcol}_{r}(G, S)=\max _{C \in \mathcal{C}} \mathrm{wcol}_{r}(C, S \cap V(C))
$$

Observation 12. Let $G$ be a graph and let $S, S^{\prime} \subseteq V(G)$. For every nonnegative integer $r$, we have

$$
\mathrm{wcol}_{r}\left(G, S \cup S^{\prime}\right) \leqslant \mathrm{wcol}_{r}(G, S)+\mathrm{wcol}_{r}\left(G-S, S^{\prime}-S\right)
$$

Observations 10 and 11 are clear from the definition and to see Observation 12, it suffices to order all the vertices of $S$ before all the vertices of $S^{\prime}$.

Geodesics are a useful tool when bounding weak coloring numbers. For instance, Lemma 9 implies the following.

Observation 13. Let $G$ be a graph, $S \subseteq V(G)$, $\ell$ be a positive integer, and $Q_{1}, \ldots, Q_{\ell}$ be geodesics in $G$. For every nonnegative integer $r$, we have

$$
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, S \cup V\left(Q_{1}\right) \cup \cdots \cup V\left(Q_{\ell}\right)\right) \leqslant \mathrm{wcol}_{r}(G, S)+\ell(2 r+1)
$$

This inequality is witnessed by an ordering of $S \cup V\left(Q_{1}\right) \cup \cdots V\left(Q_{\ell}\right)$ obtained from the ordering $\sigma$ of $S$ witnessing $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S)$ by putting vertices from $\left(V\left(Q_{1}\right) \cup \cdots \cup V\left(Q_{\ell}\right)\right)-S$ arbitrarily.

Note that $\mathrm{wcol}_{r}(G, S)$ is not monotone with respect to $S$. For example, let $G$ be a star with the root $v$. We have $V(G)-\{v\} \subseteq V(G)$, however, $\operatorname{wcol}_{1}(G, V(G)-\{v\})=|V(G)|$ and $\operatorname{wcol}_{1}(G, V(G))=2$. On the other hand, our version of weak coloring numbers is monotone in the following sense.

Observation 14. Let $G$ be a graph, $S \subseteq V(G)$, and $U \subseteq V(G)$. For every nonnegative integer $r$, we have

$$
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G-U, S-U) \leqslant \mathrm{wcol}_{r}(G, S)
$$

The ideas of Observations 13 and 14 can be combined to obtain another property.
Observation 15. Let $G$ be a graph, $S \subseteq V(G), U \subseteq V(G)$, $\ell$ be a positive integer, and $Q_{1}, \ldots, Q_{\ell}$ be geodesics in $G$. For every nonnegative integer $r$, we have

$$
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G-U,\left(S \cup V\left(Q_{1}\right) \cup \cdots \cup V\left(Q_{\ell}\right)\right)-U\right) \leqslant \mathrm{wcol}_{r}(G-U, S-U)+\ell(2 r+1)
$$

Finally, we can decide to place a fixed subset $A$ of vertices first in the ordering and then consider the geodesic paths in the remaining graph $G-A$. This turns out to be an important trick.

Observation 16. Let $G$ be a graph, $A \subseteq V(G)$, $\ell$ be a positive integer, and $Q_{1}, \ldots, Q_{\ell}$ be geodesics in $G-A$. For every nonnegative integer $r$, we have

$$
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, A \cup V\left(Q_{1}\right) \cup \cdots \cup V\left(Q_{\ell}\right)\right) \leqslant|A|+\ell(2 r+1)
$$

To see that the observation holds, we just take an arbitrary ordering of $A \cup V\left(Q_{1}\right) \cup \cdots \cup V\left(Q_{\ell}\right)$ with vertices of $A$ preceding vertices of $V\left(Q_{1}\right) \cup \cdots \cup V\left(Q_{\ell}\right)$.

Now, we present one of the key basic tools in the proof of Theorem 5.
Lemma 17 (Lemma 7 restated). There exists a function $\delta$ such that for all positive integers $k, d$, for every connected $K_{k}$-minor-free graph $G$, for every family $\mathcal{F}$ of connected subgraphs of $G$, either there are $d$ pairwise vertex-disjoint subgraphs in $\mathcal{F}$, or there exists $S \subseteq V(G)$ such that
(a) $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$;
(b) $G[S]$ is connected;
(c) $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) \leqslant \delta(k, d) \cdot r$ for every positive integer $r$.

Lemma 17 is a consequence of the following statement from [2], which relies on the Graph Minor Structure Theorem by Robertson and Seymour.

Lemma 18 ([2, Lemma 21]). There exists a function $\gamma$ such that for all positive integers $k, d$, for every $K_{k}$-minor-free graph $G$, for every family $\mathcal{F}$ of connected subgraphs of $G$ either
(1) there are d pairwise vertex-disjoint subgraphs in $\mathcal{F}$, or
(2) there exists $A \subseteq V(G)$ with $|A| \leqslant(d-1) \gamma(k)$ and there exists a subgraph $X$ of $G$ which is the union of at most $(d-1)^{2} \gamma(k)$ geodesics in $G-A$, such that for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$ we have $V(F) \cap(V(X) \cup A) \neq \emptyset$.

Proof of Lemma 17. Let $\delta(k, d)=12(d-1)^{2} \gamma(k)$ where $\gamma$ is the function from Lemma 18. Let $G$ be a $K_{k}$-minor-free graph and let $\mathcal{F}$ be a family of connected subgraphs of $G$. Suppose that there are no $d$ pairwise disjoint members of $\mathcal{F}$, and hence, Lemma 18.(2) holds, yielding $A \subseteq V(G)$ and a subgraph $X$ of $G$ such that $|A| \leqslant(d-1) \gamma(k)$ and $X$ is the union of at
