$\operatorname{most}(d-1)^{2} \gamma(k)$ geodesics in $G-A$. Note that $G[A \cup V(X)]$ has at most $|A|+(d-1)^{2} \gamma(k)$ components. Let $Q_{1}, \ldots, Q_{\ell}$ be a family of at most $(d-1) \gamma(k)+(d-1)^{2} \gamma(k)-1$ geodesics in $G$ such that the set $S=A \cup V(X) \cup \bigcup_{\ell \in[\ell]} V\left(Q_{\imath}\right)$ induces a connected subgraph in $G$. In particular, $\ell \leqslant 2(d-1)^{2} \gamma(k)$. By Observations 13 and 16, for every positive integer $r$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) & \leqslant \operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, A \cup V(X))+\ell(2 r+1) \\
& \leqslant|A|+(d-1)^{2} \gamma(k)(2 r+1)+\ell(2 r+1) \\
& \leqslant(d-1) \gamma(k)+(d-1)^{2} \gamma(k)(2 r+1)+2(d-1)^{2} \gamma(k)(2 r+1) \\
& \leqslant 4(d-1)^{2} \gamma(k)(2 r+1) \leqslant \delta(k, d) r
\end{aligned}
$$

It is easy to derive an upper bound on weak coloring numbers of trees. It suffices to root a given tree and order the vertices in an elimination order. Namely, an elimination ordering of a tree $T$ rooted in $s \in V(T)$ is an ordering $\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{|V(T)|}\right)$ of $V(T)$ such that $x_{1}=s$ and for every $i \in\{2, \ldots,|V(T)|\}, N\left(x_{i}\right) \cap\left\{x_{j} \mid j \in[i-1]\right\}=\{y\}$ where $y$ is the parent of $x_{i}$. Note that in such an ordering a vertex weakly reaches only its ancestors. See Figure 5.

Observation 19. Let $T$ be a tree. For every positive integer $r$, we have

$$
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(T) \leqslant r+1
$$

More precisely, for every elimination ordering $\sigma$ of $T$, for every $u \in V(T)$, and for every positive integer $r$ we have

$$
\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[T, \sigma, u] \subseteq A_{r, x}
$$

where $A_{r, x}$ is the set of ancestors of $x$, including $x$ itself, in distance at most $r$. Note that $\left|A_{r, x}\right| \leqslant r+1$.

This idea can be generalized to elimination orderings of tree decompositions - see [8].

# 4. Rooted 2-TREEDEPTH 

First, we recall the definition of rooted 2-treedepth. For every graph $G$,
(r1) $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)=0$ if $G$ is the null graph,
(r2) $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)=1$ if $G$ is a one vertex graph, and otherwise
(r3) $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)$ is the minimum of $\max \left\{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(A), \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-V(A))+|V(A) \cap V(B)|\right\}$ over all separations $(A, B)$ of $G$ of order at most one with $V(A) \neq \emptyset$ and $V(B)-V(A) \neq \emptyset$.

As mentioned in Section 2.1, the following properties are direct consequences of the definition. For every graph $G$,
(r4) $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)$ is the maximum of $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(C)$ over all components $C$ of $G$ when $G$ is not connected;
(r5) $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)$ is the minimum of $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G-v)+1$ over all vertices $v$ of $G$ when $G$ consists of one block;
(r6) $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)$ is the minimum of $\max \left\{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(A), \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-V(A))+1\right\}$ over all separations $(A, B)$ of $G$ of order one with $V(A) \cap V(B)$ consisting of a cut-vertex, when $G$ is connected and consists of more than one block;
(r7) $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G) \leqslant 1+\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G-u)$;
(r8) $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G) \leqslant \max \left\{2, \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G-u)\right\}$ for every $u \in V(G)$ of degree at most 1.
Item (r3) in the definition can be in fact strengthened in the following way. For every graph $G$,
(r9) $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)$ is the minimum of $\max \left\{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(A), \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-V(A))+|V(A) \cap V(B)|\right\}$ over all separations $(A, B)$ of $G$ of order at most one with $V(A) \neq \emptyset$ and $V(B)-V(A) \neq \emptyset$ such that $B$ is a block.

To see that, consider a separation $(A, B)$ of $G$ of order one with $V(A) \neq \emptyset$ and $V(B)-V(A) \neq \emptyset$ such that $B$ is a block. By (r3), $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G) \leqslant \max \left\{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(A), \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-V(A))+1\right\}$. For the other inequality, observe that we can assume $G$ connected by (r4). Suppose that $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)=$ $\max \left\{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(A), \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-V(A))+1\right\}$ where $(A, B)$ is a separation of $G$ of order one with $V(A) \neq \emptyset$ and $V(B)-V(A) \neq \emptyset$. Let $\left(A^{\prime}, B^{\prime}\right)$ be a separation of $G$ of order one with $V\left(A^{\prime}\right) \neq \emptyset$ and $V\left(B^{\prime}\right)-V\left(A^{\prime}\right) \neq \emptyset$ such that $B^{\prime}$ is a block, $A \subseteq A^{\prime}$ and $B^{\prime} \subseteq B$. Then $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(A^{\prime}\right) \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)$ and $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(B^{\prime}-V\left(A^{\prime}\right)\right)+1 \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-V(A))+1 \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)$.

As an illustration of the definition of rooted 2 -treedepth, we characterize graphs having the values of $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}$ in $\{1,2\}$. First, note the following straightforward observation.

Observation 20. For every graph $G$, we have $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G) \leqslant 1$ if and only if $G$ has no edges.
Next, we show that for every tree $T$, we have $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(T) \leqslant 2$. We proceed by induction on the number of vertices of $T$. For the base case, $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(K_{1}\right)=1 \leqslant 2$. In general, if $x$ is a leaf of $T$ whose parent is $y$, then the separation $(T-x, T[\{x, y\})]$ witnesses $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(T) \leqslant$ $\max \left\{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(T-x), \operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(K_{1}\right)+1\right\} \leqslant 2$.

We are about to show that $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}$ is minor-monotone. Note that this yields a characterization of graphs with $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}$ at most two. Namely, $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G) \leqslant 2$ if and only if $G$ is a forest. Indeed, observe that $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(K_{3}\right)=3$.

Observation 21. For every graph $G$, we have $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G) \leqslant 2$ if and only if $G$ is a forest.
Lemma 22. For all graphs $G, H$, if $H$ is a minor of $G$, then

$$
\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(H) \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)
$$

Proof. We proceed by induction on $|V(G)|$. When $|V(G)| \leqslant 1$, then the assertion holds. Hence, let $G$ be a graph on at least two vertices. There is a separation $(A, B)$ of $G$ of order at most one such that $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)=\max \left\{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(A), \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-V(A))+|V(A) \cap V(B)|\right\}, V(B)-V(A) \neq \emptyset$, and $V(A) \neq \emptyset$. In particular, $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(A) \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)$ and $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-V(A))+|V(A) \cap V(B)| \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)$.

We claim that $H$ has a separation $\left(A^{\prime}, B^{\prime}\right)$ such that $A^{\prime}$ is a minor of $A, B^{\prime}-V\left(A^{\prime}\right)$ is a minor of $B-V(A)$, and $\left|V\left(A^{\prime}\right) \cap V\left(B^{\prime}\right)\right| \leqslant|V(A) \cap V(B)|$. Indeed, let $\left(C_{x} \mid x \in V(H)\right)$ be a model

of $H$ in $G$, and let

$$
\begin{aligned}
& A^{\prime}=H\left[\left\{x \in V(H) \mid C_{x} \cap V(A) \neq \emptyset\right\}\right] \\
& B^{\prime}=H\left[\left\{x \in V(H) \mid C_{x} \cap V(B) \neq \emptyset\right\}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that $\left(A^{\prime}, B^{\prime}\right)$ is a separation of $H$. Moreover, by construction $\left|V\left(A^{\prime}\right) \cap V\left(B^{\prime}\right)\right| \leqslant|V(A) \cap$ $V(B) \mid$. In addition, since $|V(A) \cap V(B)| \leqslant 1, A^{\prime}$ is a minor of $A$ and $B^{\prime}-V\left(A^{\prime}\right)$ is a minor of $B-V(A)$. Observe that since $\left|V\left(A^{\prime}\right) \cap V\left(B^{\prime}\right)\right| \leqslant 1,\left(C_{x} \cap V(A) \mid x \in V\left(A^{\prime}\right)\right)$ is a model of $A^{\prime}$ in $A$, and $\left(C_{x} \cap(V(B)-V(A)) \mid x \in V\left(B^{\prime}\right)-V\left(A^{\prime}\right)\right)$ is a model of $B^{\prime}-V\left(A^{\prime}\right)$ in $B$.

Since $V(B)-V(A) \neq \emptyset$, and $V(A) \neq \emptyset$, we have $|V(A)|<|V(G)|$ and $|V(B-V(A))|<|V(G)|$. Therefore, by induction hypothesis, since $A^{\prime}$ is a minor of $A$ and $B^{\prime}-V\left(A^{\prime}\right)$ is a minor of $B-V(A), \operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(A^{\prime}\right) \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(A)$ and $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(B^{\prime}-V\left(A^{\prime}\right)\right) \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-V(A))$. We deduce that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(H) & \leqslant \max \left\{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(A^{\prime}\right), \operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(B^{\prime}-V\left(A^{\prime}\right)\right)+\left|V\left(A^{\prime}\right) \cap V\left(B^{\prime}\right)\right|\right\} \\
& \leqslant \max \left\{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(A), \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-V(A))+|V(A) \cap V(B)|\right\} \\
& =\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)
\end{aligned}
$$

It is evident from the definitions that the parameters $\mathrm{td}_{2}$ and $\mathrm{rtd}_{2}$ are closely related. Indeed, for instance, $\mathrm{td}_{2}$ is minor-monotone too - one can see this by following the above proof with a slight modification (we do not give an explicit proof since we never use this fact). In the next part of this section, we discuss relations between $\mathrm{rtd}_{2}$ and $\mathrm{td}_{2}$. Namely, we show that the two parameters are linearly tied.

Lemma 23. For every graph $G$ with at least one edge,

$$
\operatorname{td}_{2}(G) \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G) \leqslant 2 \operatorname{td}_{2}(G)-2
$$

Proof. First, we prove that $\operatorname{td}_{2}(G) \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)$ for every graph $G$. We proceed by induction on $|V(G)|$. When $G$ is a null graph, we have $\operatorname{td}_{2}(G)=\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)=0$ and when $G$ is a one-vertex graph, we have $\operatorname{td}_{2}(G)=\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)=1$. Thus, we assume that $|V(G)| \geqslant 2$. If $G$ consists of one block, then by (г5) and induction hypothesis,

$$
\operatorname{td}_{2}(G)=\min _{v \in V(G)} \operatorname{td}_{2}(G-v)+1 \leqslant \min _{v \in V(G)} \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G-v)+1=\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)
$$

If $G$ consists of blocks $B_{1}, \ldots, B_{k}$ for $k>1$, then by induction hypothesis,

$$
\operatorname{td}_{2}(G)=\max _{i \in[k]} \operatorname{td}_{2}\left(B_{i}\right) \leqslant \max _{i \in[k]} \operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(B_{i}\right) \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)
$$

Now, we prove the other inequality for every graph $G$ with at least one edge. We again proceed by induction on $|V(G)|$. If $\operatorname{td}_{2}(G)=2$, then $G$ is a forest with at least one edge, and so as mentioned earlier $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)=\operatorname{td}_{2}(G)=2$. Now assume that $\operatorname{td}_{2}(G) \geqslant 3$, and so in particular $|V(G)| \geqslant 3$, and that the result holds for smaller graphs. In particular, for every nonnull graph $H$ with $|V(H)|<|V(G)|$, either $H$ has no edge and so $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(H)=\operatorname{td}_{2}(H)=1$, or $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(H) \leqslant 2 \operatorname{td}_{2}(H)-2$. In both cases, $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(H) \leqslant \max \left\{1,2 \operatorname{td}_{2}(H)-2\right\}$. By (г9), there is a separation $(A, B)$ of $G$ of order at most one such that $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)=\max \left\{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(A), \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-V(A))+\right.$ $\left.|V(A) \cap V(B)|\right\}, V(B)-V(A) \neq \emptyset, V(A) \neq \emptyset$, and $B$ is a block of $G$. If $|V(A) \cap V(B)|=0$, then $B-V(A)=B$ and so

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G) & =\max \left\{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(A), \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B)\right\} \\
& \leqslant \max \left\{\max \left\{1,2 \operatorname{td}_{2}(A)-2\right\}, \max \left\{1,2 \operatorname{td}_{2}(B)-2\right\}\right\} \\
& =\max \left\{1,2 \max \left\{\operatorname{td}_{2}(A), \operatorname{td}_{2}(B)\right\}-2\right\} \\
& =2 \operatorname{td}_{2}(G)-2
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, we assume that $|V(A) \cap V(B)|=1$ and $V(A) \cap V(B)=\{u\}$. There exists $v \in V(B)$ such that $\operatorname{td}_{2}(B-v)=\operatorname{td}_{2}(B)-1$. Then, by (17),

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-u) & \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-u-v)+1 \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-v)+1 \\
& \leqslant \max \left\{1,2 \operatorname{td}_{2}(B-v)-2\right\}+1 \\
& =\max \left\{2,2 \operatorname{td}_{2}(B-v)-1\right\} \\
& \leqslant \max \left\{2,2 \operatorname{td}_{2}(B)-3\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, since $\operatorname{td}_{2}(G) \geqslant 3$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G) & =\max \left\{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(A), \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-u)+1\right\} \\
& \leqslant \max \left\{\max \left\{1,2 \operatorname{td}_{2}(A)-2\right\}, \max \left\{2,2 \operatorname{td}_{2}(B)-3\right\}+1\right\} \\
& =\max \left\{3,2 \operatorname{td}_{2}(A)-2,2 \operatorname{td}_{2}(B)-3+1\right\} \\
& \leqslant \max \left\{3,2 \operatorname{td}_{2}(G)-2\right\} \\
& =2 \operatorname{td}_{2}(G)-2
\end{aligned}
$$

The bounds in Lemma 23 are tight. Indeed, for every positive integer $n$, we have $\operatorname{td}_{2}\left(K_{n}\right)=$ $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(K_{n}\right)=n$, which witnesses that the first inequality is tight. For the second one, see Lemma 25, which we precede with a simple observation. Note that this observation is also true for $\mathrm{td}_{2}$, namely, $\operatorname{td}_{2}\left(K_{1} \oplus G\right)=1+\operatorname{td}_{2}(G)-$ again, the proof is very similar and we omit it.

Observation 24. For every graph $G$,

$$
\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(K_{1} \oplus G\right)=1+\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)
$$

Proof. Let $G$ be a graph and let $s$ the vertex of $K_{1}$ in $K_{1} \oplus G$. By definition, $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(K_{1} \oplus G\right) \leqslant$ $1+\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)$. For the other inequality, we proceed by induction on $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)$. The assertion is clear when $G$ is the null graph, thus, assume that $G$ is not the null graph. If $G$ is not connected, then $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)=\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(C)$ for some component $C$ of $G$, and since $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(K_{1} \oplus G\right) \geqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(K_{1} \oplus C\right)$, it suffices to show $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(K_{1} \oplus C\right) \geqslant 1+\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(C)$. Therefore, we assume that $G$ is connected. Since $K_{1} \oplus G$ is also connected, there is a separation $(A, B)$ of $K_{1} \oplus G$ of order one such that $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)=\max \left\{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(A), \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-V(A))+1\right\}, V(B)-V(A) \neq \emptyset$, and $V(A) \neq \emptyset$. Since $s$ is adjacent to all other vertices in $K_{1} \oplus G$, the only possibility is that $V(A)=\{s\}$ and $V(B)=V\left(K_{1} \oplus G\right)$. It follows that $B-V(A)$ contains a subgraph isomorphic to $G$, and thus, $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(K_{1} \oplus G\right) \geqslant 1+\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-V(A)) \geqslant 1+\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)$.

Lemma 25. For every integer $k$ with $k \geqslant 2$, there is a graph $G$ with $\operatorname{td}_{2}(G) \leqslant k$ and $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G) \geqslant$ $2 k-2$.

Proof. We define inductively graphs $H_{k, \ell}$ with two distinguished vertices $u_{k, \ell}$ and $v_{k, \ell}$ for every integers $k, \ell$ with $k, \ell \geqslant 2$. For $k=2, H_{k, \ell}$ is a path on $\ell$ vertices and $u_{k, \ell}, v_{k, \ell}$ are its endpoints. For $k \geqslant 3, H_{k, \ell}$ is obtained from two disjoint copies $H_{1}, H_{2}$ of $K_{1} \oplus H_{k-1, \ell}$ by identifying the copy of $v_{k-1, \ell}$ in $H_{1}$ with the copy of $u_{k-1, \ell}$ in $H_{2}$. The vertices $u_{k, \ell}, v_{k, \ell}$ are then respectively the copy of $u_{k-1, \ell}$ in $H_{1}$ and the copy of $v_{k-1, \ell}$ in $H_{2}$. See Figure 6.

By induction on $k$, we show that $\operatorname{td}_{2}\left(H_{k, \ell}\right) \leqslant k$ and $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(H_{k, \ell}\right) \geqslant 2 k-2$ for all integers $k, \ell$ with $\ell \geqslant k \geqslant 2$. When $k=2, H_{2, \ell}$ is a path on at least two vertices and so $\operatorname{td}_{2}\left(H_{2, \ell}\right)=\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(H_{2, \ell}\right)=$ 2. Now suppose that $k \geqslant 3$. First, observe that $H_{k, \ell}$ has exactly two blocks $H_{1}, H_{2}$, both isomorphic to $K_{1} \oplus H_{k-1, \ell}$. Hence, $\operatorname{td}_{2}\left(H_{k, \ell}\right) \leqslant \operatorname{td}_{2}\left(K_{1} \oplus H_{k-1, \ell}\right) \leqslant 1+\operatorname{td}_{2}\left(H_{k-1, \ell}\right) \leqslant k$ by induction hypothesis. Let $v$ be the unique cut-vertex of $H_{k, \ell}$. Since $H_{k, \ell}$ is connected and consists of more than one block, by (r6), there is a separation $(A, B)$ of $H_{k, \ell}$ such that

![img-5.jpeg](img-5.jpeg)

Figure 6. The proof of Lemma 25 implies that $\operatorname{td}_{2}\left(H_{4,4}\right) \leqslant 4$ and $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(H_{4,4}\right) \geqslant 6$.
$V(A) \cap V(B)=\{v\}$ and $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(H_{k, \ell}\right)=\max \left\{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(A), \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-v)+1\right\}$. It follows that the graph $B-v$ contains $K_{1} \oplus H_{k-1, \ell-1}$ as a subgraph, and so, applying Observation 24,

$$
\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(H_{k, \ell-1}\right) \geqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-v)+1 \geqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(K_{1} \oplus H_{k-1, \ell-1}\right)+1 \geqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(H_{k-1, \ell-1}\right)+2 \geqslant 2 k-2
$$

This concludes the proof of the lemma.
In Section 1, we mentioned several times the construction given in [8]. Let us now finally introduce it properly, and later show the equivalent description of rooted 2 -treedepth using this construction.

Let $d$ be a positive integer, let $B, H$ be two graphs, and let $u$ be a vertex of $H$. Recall that $L_{d}(B, H, u)$ is the graph obtained in the following process. Take a copy of $B$ and $d|V(B)|$ copies of $H$. Label the latter $H_{i, x}$ for each $i \in[d]$ and $x \in V(B)$. Next, for each $x \in V(B)$ identify $x$ and $u$ in each $H_{i, x}$ for $i \in[d]$. See Figure 2.

Moreover, for all nonnegative integers $r, t$ the graph $G_{r, t}$ is defined recursively by

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
G_{0, t}=G_{r, 0}=K_{1} \\
G_{r, t}=L_{\binom{r+t}{t}}\left(G_{r-1, t}, K_{1} \oplus G_{r, t-1}, u\right) \text { if } r, t>0
\end{array}\right.
$$

where $u$ is the vertex of $K_{1}$ in $K_{1} \oplus G_{r, t-1}$.
Lemma 26. For every graph $G$ with at least one edge, $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)$ is equal to the least $t$ such that there exists a nonnegative integer $r$ with $G \subseteq G_{r, t-1}$.

Proof. First, we show that for every $G$ with at least one edge and every integer $t \geqslant 0$ such that there exists $r \geqslant 0$ with $G \subseteq G_{r, t-1}$, we have $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G) \leqslant t$. Since $G$ has an edge, we have $t \geqslant 2$. By Lemma 22, it is enough to show that $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(G_{r, t-1}\right) \leqslant t$ for all integers $r, t$ with $r \geqslant 0$ and $t \geqslant 2$. We proceed by induction on $t+r$. If $t=2$ or $r=0$, then $G_{r, t-1}$ is a tree and the result follows. Now suppose $t \geqslant 3, r \geqslant 1$. By the definition of $G_{r, t-1}$, there is a sequence $H_{0}, \ldots, H_{m}$ of graphs such that $H_{0}=G_{r-1, t-1}, H_{m}=G_{r, t-1}$, and for every $i \in[m], H_{i}$ contains a block $B_{i}$ containing a unique cut vertex $r_{i}$ of $H_{i}$ in $B_{i}$, which is such that $B_{i}-r_{i}$ is isomorphic to $G_{r, t-2}$ and $H_{i-1}=H_{i}-V\left(B_{i}-r_{i}\right)$.

We claim that $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(H_{i}\right) \leqslant t$ for every $i \in\{0, \ldots, m\}$. We proceed by induction on $i$. The main induction hypothesis gives $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(H_{0}\right)=\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(G_{r-1, t-1}\right) \leqslant t$. Now let $i \in[m]$. The graph $H_{i}$ has a block $B_{i}$ containing a unique cut vertex $r_{i}$ of $H_{i}$ such that $B_{i}-r_{i}$ is isomorphic to $G_{r, t-2}$ and $H_{i-1}=H_{i}-V\left(B_{i}-r_{i}\right)$. Then $\left(H_{i-1}, B_{i}\right)$ is a separation of $H_{i}$ of order at most one, and hence by induction hypothesis $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(H_{i}\right) \leqslant \max \left\{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(H_{i-1}\right), \operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(G_{r, t-2}\right)+1\right\} \leqslant t$. For $i=m$, this proves that $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(G_{r, t-1}\right) \leqslant t$ as asserted.

Next, we prove the opposite implication, i.e., if $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G) \leqslant t$ then there exists $r \geqslant 0$ such that $G \subseteq G_{r, t-1}$. We proceed by induction on $(t,|V(G)|)$ in the lexicographic order. Since $G$ has an edge, we must have $|V(G)| \geqslant 2$ and $t \geqslant 2$. Suppose that $t=2$, and so, $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G) \leqslant 2$, which implies by Observation 21 that $G$ is a forest. There is a vertex $x$ of $G$ of degree at most one. Since $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G-x) \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G) \leqslant t$, by induction hypothesis, there exists a nonnegative integer $r$ such that $G-x \subseteq G_{r, 1}$, and so $G \subseteq G_{r+1,1}$.

Now, suppose that $t \geqslant 3$. There is a separation $(A, B)$ of $G$ of order at most one such that $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(A) \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G), \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-V(A)) \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)-|V(A) \cap V(B)|, V(B)-V(A) \neq \emptyset$ and $V(A) \neq \emptyset$. We take such a separation $(A, B)$ with $|V(A) \cap V(B)|=1$ if possible. Assume that it is impossible, and so, $|V(A) \cap V(B)|=0$. Then we claim that every component of $G$ has only one vertex. Indeed, by (r4) there is a component $C$ of $G$ such that $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)=\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(C)$. If $C$ has more than one vertex, there is a separation $\left(A^{\prime}, B^{\prime}\right)$ of $C$ of order at most one such that $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(A^{\prime}\right) \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(C), \operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(B^{\prime}-V\left(A^{\prime}\right)\right) \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(C)-\left|V\left(A^{\prime}\right) \cap V\left(B^{\prime}\right)\right|, V\left(B^{\prime}\right)-V\left(A^{\prime}\right) \neq \emptyset$ and $V\left(A^{\prime}\right) \neq \emptyset$. Note that $\left|V\left(A^{\prime}\right) \cap V\left(B^{\prime}\right)\right|=1$ as $C$ is connected. However, $\left\{(G-V(C)) \cup A^{\prime}, B^{\prime}\right\}$ contradicts the impossibility assumption. This proves that every component of $G$ has one vertex, and so, $G$ has no edges, which is a contradiction.

We have $|V(A) \cap V(B)|=1,|V(A)|<|V(G)|$, and $|V(B-V(A))|<|V(G)|$. Moreover, $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(A) \leqslant t$ and $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(B-V(A)) \leqslant t-1$, therefore, by induction hypothesis, there exist nonnegative integers $r$ and $r^{\prime}$ such that $A \subseteq G_{r, t-1}$ and $B-V(A) \subseteq G_{r^{\prime}, t-2}$. It follows that $B \subseteq K_{1} \oplus G_{r^{\prime}, t-2}$, and so $G \subseteq G_{\max \left\{r+1, r^{\prime}\right\}, t-1}$.

We finish this section with another universal construction for graphs of rooted 2 -treedepth at most $t$, which will be useful in the proofs of Theorem 5 and Theorem 6. Given a graph $G$, we will define a graph $T_{h, d}(G)$ for all positive integers $h, d$, whose blocks are all isomorphic to $K_{1} \oplus G$.

Let $G$ be a graph and let $d$ be a positive integer. For every positive integer $h$, we define the graph $T_{h, d}(G)$ with one distinguished vertex, which we call the root of $T_{h, d}(G)$. When $h=1$, let $T_{1, d}(G)=K_{1} \oplus G$, and let the vertex of $K_{1}$ be the root. When $h>1$, fix a copy of $T_{h-1, d}(G)$ with the root $s$, and let

$$
T_{h, d}(G)=L_{d}\left(K_{1} \oplus G, T_{h-1, d}(G), s\right)
$$

As the root of $T_{h, d}(G)$, we distinguish the vertex of $K_{1}$ in the copy of $K_{1} \oplus G$ given as the first argument to $L_{d}$. See Figure 7.

Lemma 27. For every graph $G$, for all positive integers $h, d$, we have

$$
\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(T_{h, d}(G)\right)=\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)+1
$$

Proof. Let $G$ be a graph and let $h, d$ be positive integers. First, $T_{h, d}(G)$ contains $K_{1} \oplus G$ as a subgraph, and so $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(T_{h, d}(G)\right) \geqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)+1$ by Observation 24 and Lemma 22. We now prove $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(T_{h, d}(G)\right) \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)+1$. Let $\mathcal{B}$ be the family of all the blocks of $T_{h, d}(G)$. For every $B \in \mathcal{B}, B$ is isomorphic to $K_{1} \oplus G=T_{1, d}(G)$, and we denote by $s_{B}$ the root of $B$. By the definition of $T_{h, d}(G)$, one can inductively construct a tree $T$ with $V(T)=\mathcal{B}$ such that, for every $B \in \mathcal{B}$ which is not the root, if $B^{\prime}$ is the parent of $B$ in $T$, then $s_{B}$ belongs to $V\left(B^{\prime}\right)$. By induction on $|V(T)|$, applying (r6) to a leaf of $T$, we conclude that $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(T_{h, d}(G)\right) \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(K_{1} \oplus G\right) \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)+1$.

Lemma 28. For every nonnull graph $G$, there exists a graph $H$ such that
(a) $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(H) \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)-1$ and
(b) $G \subseteq T_{h, d}(H)$ for some positive integers $h$ and $d$.

![img-6.jpeg](img-6.jpeg)

Figure 7. An illustration of the construction of $T_{h, d}(G)$, which is obtained from $K_{1} \oplus G$ by gluing on every vertex $d$ copies of $T_{h-1, d}(G)$.

Proof. If $G$ has no edges, then we set $H=K_{1}$ and the assertion follows, thus assume that $G$ has at least one edge. Let $t=\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(G)-1$. By Lemma 26, there exists a nonnegative integer $r$ such that $G \subseteq G_{r, t}$. Hence, it is enough to show that there exists a graph $H$ with $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(H) \leqslant t$ and $G_{r, t} \subseteq T_{h, d}(H)$ for some positive integers $h, d$. Let $\mathcal{B}$ be the family of all the blocks of $G_{r, t}$. Recall that $G_{r, t}=L_{\binom{r+t}{i}}\left(G_{r-1, t}, K_{1} \oplus G_{r, t-1}, u\right)$ if $r, t>0$. Thus, each $B \in \mathcal{B}$ is either isomorphic to $K_{1} \oplus G_{r, t-1}$, or is a block of $G_{r-1, t}$. Thus, for each $B \in \mathcal{B}$ there is a nonnegative integer $r^{\prime}$ with $r^{\prime} \leqslant r$ such that every $B$ is isomorphic to $K_{1} \oplus G_{r^{\prime}, t-1}$. This implies that for each $B \in \mathcal{B}$ we have $B \subseteq K_{1} \oplus G_{r, t-1}$.

We denote by $s_{B}$ the vertex of $B$ corresponding to $K_{1}$. By the definition of $G_{r, t}$, one can inductively construct a rooted tree $T$ with $V(T)=\mathcal{B}$ such that for every $B \in \mathcal{B}$ which is not the root, the vertex $s_{B}$ belongs to $V\left(B^{\prime}\right)$ if $B^{\prime}$ is the parent of $B$ in $T$ (in the same way as in Lemma 27). Moreover, $B-s_{B}$ is isomorphic to $G_{r^{\prime}, t-1}$ for some integer $r^{\prime}$ with $r^{\prime} \leqslant r$. Let $S$ be the root of $T$. Let $h$ be the vertex-height of $T$, and let $d$ be the maximum number of children of a vertex in $T$. We claim that $H=G_{r, t-1}$ satisfies the required conditions. The first assertion is clear by Lemma 26, thus, it suffices to prove that $G_{r, t} \subseteq T_{h, d}\left(G_{r, t-1}\right)$. To this end, we show by induction the following property. For every subtree $T^{\prime}$ of $T$ rooted in $S$ of vertex-height $h^{\prime}$, we have $\bigcup_{B \in V\left(T^{\prime}\right)} V(B) \subseteq T_{h^{\prime}, d}\left(G_{r, t-1}\right)$.

When $h^{\prime}=1,\left|V\left(T^{\prime}\right)\right|=1$ and so $G\left[\bigcup_{B \in V\left(T^{\prime}\right)} V(B)\right] \subseteq K_{1} \oplus G_{r, t-1}=T_{1, d}\left(G_{r, t-1}\right)$. Now suppose that $h^{\prime}>1$. Let $L$ be the set of all vertices of $T^{\prime}$ at distance $h^{\prime}-1$ from $S$. By induction hypothesis and because $T^{\prime}-L$ has vertex-height $h^{\prime}-1$, we have $\bigcup_{B \in V\left(T^{\prime}-L\right)} V(B) \subseteq$ $T_{h^{\prime}-1, d}\left(G_{r, t-1}\right)$. Then, $G\left[\bigcup_{B \in V\left(T^{\prime}\right)} V(B)\right]$ is obtained from $G\left[\bigcup_{B \in V\left(T^{\prime}-L\right)} V(B)\right]$ by gluing on every vertex at most $d$ blocks isomorphic to a subgraph of $K_{1} \oplus G_{r, t-1}$. Hence $G\left[\bigcup_{B \in V\left(T^{\prime}\right)} V(B)\right] \subseteq T_{h^{\prime}, d}\left(G_{r, t-1}\right)$. Applying the above to $T^{\prime}=T$ ends the proof.

Having a model of $T_{h, d}(X)$ in some graph $G$, sometimes it will be handy to insist that a given vertex $u \in V(G)$ is in the branch set of the root of $T_{h, d}(X)$. To this end, we introduce another auxiliary construction and we prove Lemma 29 below.

For every graph $X$ and for all positive integers $d, h$, let $T_{h, d}^{\prime}(X)$ be the result of taking two disjoint copies of $T_{h, d}(X)$ and identifying their roots - we call this new vertex the root of $T_{h, d}^{\prime}(X)$.

Lemma 29. Let $X$ be a graph and let $h, d$ be positive integers. Let $G$ be a connected graph and let $u \in V(G)$. If $\left(A_{x} \mid x \in V\left(T_{h, d}^{\prime}(X)\right)\right)$ is a model of $T_{h, d}^{\prime}(X)$ in $G$, then there exists a model $\left(B_{x} \mid x \in V\left(T_{h, d}(X)\right)\right)$ of $T_{h, d}(X)$ in $G$ such that
(a) $u \in B_{s}$ where $s$ is the root of $T_{h, d}(X)$ and
(b) for every $x \in V\left(T_{h, d}(X)\right)$, there exists $y \in V\left(T_{h, d}^{\prime}(X)\right)$ such that $A_{y} \subseteq B_{x}$.

Proof. Observe that $T_{h, d}^{\prime}(X)$ has a separation $\left(H_{1}, H_{2}\right)$ such that $V\left(H_{1}\right) \cap V\left(H_{2}\right)=\left\{s^{\prime}\right\}$ where $s^{\prime}$ is the root of $T_{h, d}^{\prime}(X)$, and $H_{i}$ is isomorphic to $T_{h, d}(X)$ for each $i \in\{1,2\}$.

Let $A$ be the union of all branch sets $A_{x}$ for $x \in V\left(T_{h, d}^{\prime}(X)\right)$. Fix a path $P$ in $G$ from $u$ to any vertex of $A$ with no internal vertices in $A$. Suppose that the endpoint of $P$ in $A$ is contained in $A_{x}$ for some $x_{0} \in V\left(T_{h, d}^{\prime}(X)\right)$ Let $\{i, j\}=\{1,2\}$ be such that $x_{0} \in V\left(H_{i}\right)$. Let $B_{s}=V(P) \cup \bigcup_{x \in V\left(H_{i}\right)} A_{x}$ and $B_{y}=A_{y}$ for every $y \in V\left(H_{j}\right)-\{s\}$. Then $\left(B_{y} \mid y \in V\left(H_{j}\right)\right)$ is a model of $T_{h, d}(X)$ in $G$ satisfying the conclusion of the lemma.

# 5. The base case: GraphS with no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of a given tree 

The proof of Theorem 5 is by induction. The technical statement of the induction is stated in Theorem 8. In this section, we provide the base case for the induction, that is, the case where $X$ is a forest. It turns out that methods used in the so-called theory of product structure of graphs are useful in the study of weak coloring numbers. For instance, the main result of [2] is actually a product structure result and the weak coloring numbers bound follows from a slight adjustment of the argument. In the material of this section, we are strongly inspired by another product structure paper by Dujmović, Hickingbotham, Joret, Micek, Morin, and Wood $[3]$.

For all positive integers $h$ and $d$, we denote by $F_{h, d}$ the (rooted) complete $d$-ary tree of vertexheight $h$. In particular, $F_{2, d}$ is the star with $d$ leaves. Note that for every tree $X$, there exist positive integers $h, d$ such that $X \subseteq F_{h, d}$.

We start with the case where $X$ is a star. Let $\delta$ be the function given by Lemma 17.
In the following proof, we need the notion of path decompositions. General tree decompositions are discussed in detail in Section 7. Let $G$ be a graph. A sequence of subsets $\left(W_{0}, \ldots, W_{\ell}\right)$ of $V(G)$ is a path decomposition of $G$ if
(i) for every $u \in V(G)$, the set $\left\{i \in\{0, \ldots, \ell\}: u \in W_{i}\right\}$ is a nonempty interval, and
(ii) for every edge $u v \in E(G)$, there exists $i \in\{0, \ldots, \ell\}$ with $u, v \in W_{i}$.

Lemma 30. Let $k, d$ be positive integers. Let $G$ be a connected $K_{k}$-minor-free graph, and let $\mathcal{F}$ be a family of connected subgraphs of $G$ such that $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $F_{2, d}$. For every nonempty $U \subseteq V(G)$ such that $G[U]$ is connected, there is a path decomposition $\left(W_{0}, \ldots, W_{\ell}\right)$ of $G$ with $\ell \geqslant 1$ and sets $R_{2}, \ldots, R_{\ell} \subseteq V(G)$ such that for $S=U \cup \bigcup_{i \in\{2, \ldots, \ell\}}\left(W_{i-1} \cap W_{i}\right)$,
(a) $W_{0}=U$;
(b) $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$;
(c) $G[S]$ is connected;

![img-7.jpeg](img-7.jpeg)

Figure 8. We illustrate the statement of Lemma 30. The green area is a given set $U$, which should become $W_{0}$. The set $R_{3}$ has to satisfy $W_{3} \cap W_{4} \subseteq$ $R_{3} \subseteq W_{0} \cup W_{1} \cup W_{2} \cup W_{3} \cup W_{4}$ and we want $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, R_{3}\right)$ to be low. We do not depict all the sets $R_{i}$ for readability.
(d) $G\left[R_{i}\right]$ is connected for every $i \in\{2, \ldots, \ell\}$;
(e) $W_{i-1} \cap W_{i} \subseteq R_{i} \subseteq \bigcup_{j \in\{0, \ldots, i-1\}} W_{j}$ for every $i \in\{2, \ldots, \ell\}$;
(f) $W_{i}$ and $W_{i+2}$ are disjoint for every $i \in\{0, \ldots, \ell-2\}$; and
(g) $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, R_{i}\right) \leqslant(\delta(k, d+1)+3) \cdot r$ for every $i \in\{2, \ldots, \ell\}$ and for every positive integer $r$.

The statement of the lemma is visualized in Figure 8.

Proof. In the proof we define many objects, they are depicted in Figure 9. We proceed by induction on $|V(G)|-|U|$. Let $U \subseteq V(G)$ be nonempty such that $G[U]$ is connected. If $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{G-U}=\emptyset$, then it suffices to take $W_{0}=W_{1}=U, \ell=1$. In particular, this is the case for $U=V(G)$. Therefore, assume $|U|<|V(G)|$ and $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{G-U} \neq \emptyset$. Let $\mathcal{F}_{0}$ be the family of all the connected subgraphs $A$ of $G-U$ such that $A$ contains a member of $\mathcal{F}$ and $V(A) \cap N_{G}(U) \neq \emptyset$. We argue that $\mathcal{F}_{0} \neq \emptyset$. Since $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{G-U} \neq \emptyset$, there is a component $C$ of $G-U$ containing a member of $\mathcal{F}$. Since $G$ is connected, $V(C) \cap N_{G}(U) \neq \emptyset$ and so $C \in \mathcal{F}_{0}$.

Observe that any collection of $d+1$ pairwise disjoint $A_{1}, \ldots, A_{d+1} \in \mathcal{F}_{0}$ yields an $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $F_{2, d}$. Indeed, it suffices to take $U \cup A_{d+1}$ as the branch set corresponding to the root of $F_{2, d}$ and $A_{1}, \ldots, A_{d}$ as the branch sets of the remaining $d$ vertices of $F_{2, d}$. Therefore, there are no $d+1$ pairwise disjoint members of $\mathcal{F}_{0}$, and thus, by Lemma 17 applied to $G$ and $\mathcal{F}_{0}$, there exists a set $S_{0} \subseteq V(G)$ such that
17.(a) $V(F) \cap S_{0} \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}_{0}$;
17.(b) $G\left[S_{0}\right]$ is connected;
17.(c) $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, S_{0}\right) \leqslant \delta(k, d+1) \cdot r$ for every positive integer $r$.

Since $\mathcal{F}_{0} \neq \emptyset$, we have $S_{0}-U \neq \emptyset$. Let $Q$ be a $U-S_{0}$ geodesic in $G$ (possibly just a one-vertex path), and let $S_{1}=S_{0} \cup V(Q)$. Note that by 17.(b), $G\left[S_{1}\right]$ is connected.

Let $\mathcal{C}_{0}$ be the family of all the components $C$ of $G-U-S_{1}$ such that $N_{G}(U) \cap V(C)=\emptyset$. Let $U^{\prime}=V(G)-\bigcup_{C \in \mathcal{C}_{0}} V(C)$. Observe that $\left|U^{\prime}\right|>|U|$ since $S_{0}-U \neq \emptyset$ and $U^{\prime}$ contains $U \cup S_{0}$. Let $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}=\left\{F \in \mathcal{F} \mid V(F) \cap U^{\prime}=\emptyset\right\}$. By induction hypothesis applied to $G, \mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ and $U^{\prime}$, there is a path decomposition $\left(W_{0}^{\prime}, \ldots, W_{V}^{\prime}\right)$ of $G$ and sets $R_{2}^{\prime}, \ldots, R_{V}^{\prime} \subseteq V(G)$ such that for $S^{\prime}=U^{\prime} \cup \bigcup_{i \in\left\{2, \ldots, \ell^{\prime}\right\}}\left(W_{i-1}^{\prime} \cap W_{i}^{\prime}\right)$,
(a') $W_{0}^{\prime}=U^{\prime}$;
(b') $V(F) \cap S^{\prime} \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}^{\prime}$;
(c') $G\left[S^{\prime}\right]$ is connected;
(d') $G\left[R_{i}^{\prime}\right]$ is connected for every $i \in\left\{2, \ldots, \ell^{\prime}\right\}$;

![img-8.jpeg](img-8.jpeg)

Figure 9. An illustration of the considered objects in Lemma 30. Note that $S_{0}$ may intersect $U$.
(e') $W_{i-1}^{\prime} \cap W_{i}^{\prime} \subseteq R_{i}^{\prime} \subseteq \bigcup_{j \in\{0, \ldots, i-1\}} W_{j}^{\prime}$ for every $i \in\left\{2, \ldots, \ell^{\prime}\right\}$;
(f') $W_{i}^{\prime}$ and $W_{i+2}^{\prime}$ are disjoint for every $i \in\left\{0, \ldots, \ell^{\prime}-2\right\}$; and
$\left(\mathrm{g}^{\prime}\right) \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, R_{i}^{\prime}\right) \leqslant(\delta(k, d+1)+3) \cdot r$ for every $i \in\{2, \ldots, \ell\}$ and for every positive integer $r$.

Let $\ell=\ell^{\prime}+1, W_{0}=U, W_{1}=U^{\prime}, W_{2}=\left(W_{1}^{\prime}-U^{\prime}\right) \cup\left(S_{1}-U\right), W_{i}=W_{i-1}^{\prime}$ for every $i \in\{3, \ldots, \ell\}$, $R_{2}=S_{1}$, and $R_{i}=R_{i-1}^{\prime}$ for every $i \in\{3, \ldots, \ell\}$. Note that (a) holds by construction. We claim that $\left(W_{0}, \ldots, W_{\ell}\right)$ is a path decomposition of $G$ and (b)-(g) hold, which completes the proof of the lemma.

Let $u \in V(G)$. We claim that $I=\left\{i \in\{0, \ldots, \ell\} \mid u \in W_{i}\right\}$ is an interval. Since $\left(W_{0}^{\prime}, \ldots, W_{\ell^{\prime}}^{\prime}\right)$ is a path decomposition of $G, I^{\prime}=\left\{i \in\left\{0, \ldots, \ell^{\prime}\right\} \mid u \in W_{i}^{\prime}\right\}$ is an interval. If $u \notin U^{\prime}=W_{0}^{\prime}$, then $I=\left\{i \in\{2, \ldots, \ell\} \mid u \in W_{i-1}^{\prime}\right\}=\left\{i+1 \mid i \in I^{\prime}\right\}$, which is an interval too. Now suppose that $u \in U^{\prime}$, and so $0 \in I^{\prime}$. If $u \notin S_{1}-U$, then $u \notin W_{2}$ and $u \notin W_{i}^{\prime}$ for every $i \in\left\{2, \ldots, \ell^{\prime}\right\}$ by (a') and (f'). Hence $I=\{0,1\}$ if $u \in U$, and $I=\{1\}$ otherwise, which is an interval in both cases. If $u \in S_{1}-U$, then $u \notin U=W_{0}$, and so $I=\{1\} \cup\left\{i+1 \mid i \in I^{\prime}-\{0\}\right\}$, which is an interval. This proves that $I$ is an interval.

Let $u v$ be an edge of $G$. We claim that there exists $i \in\{0, \ldots, \ell\}$ such that $u, v \in W_{i}$. If there exists $i^{\prime} \in\left\{2, \ldots, \ell^{\prime}\right\}$ such that $u, v \in W_{i^{\prime}}^{\prime}$, then $u, v \in W_{i^{\prime}}^{\prime}=W_{i^{\prime}-1}$ and we are done. Now suppose that $u$ and $v$ are not both in $W_{i}^{\prime}$ for every $i \in\{2, \ldots, \ell\}$. Since $\left(W_{0}^{\prime}, \ldots, W_{\ell^{\prime}}^{\prime}\right)$ is a path decomposition of $G$, there exists $i^{\prime} \in\{0,1\}$ such that $u, v \in W_{i^{\prime}}^{\prime}$. If $i^{\prime}=0$, then $u, v \in W_{0}^{\prime}=$ $U^{\prime}=W_{1}$. Now suppose that $u$ and $v$ are not both in $W_{0}^{\prime}=U^{\prime}$, and so, in particular, $i^{\prime}=1$. Without loss of generality assume that $v \notin U^{\prime}$. It follows that $v \in W_{1}^{\prime}-U^{\prime} \subseteq W_{2}$. Let $C$ be the component of $v$ in $G-U-S_{1}$. Since $v \notin U^{\prime}, C$ belongs to $\mathcal{C}_{0}$, and so $N_{G}(V(C)) \cap U=\emptyset$. It follows that $N_{G}(V(C)) \cap U=\emptyset$, and so, $u \in S_{1}-U$. Therefore, $u \in W_{2}$, which concludes the claim. Furthermore, we obtained that $\left(W_{0}, \ldots, W_{\ell}\right)$ is a path decomposition of $G$.

We now prove (b). Consider $F \in \mathcal{F}$. If $F$ intersects $U$, then $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ since $U \subseteq S$. If $F$ intersects $S_{1}-U$, then $F$ intersects $W_{1} \cap W_{2} \subseteq S$. Now suppose that $F$ is disjoint from $U \cup S_{1}$. Let $C$ be the component containing $F$ in $G-U-S_{1}$. Since $C$ is disjoint from $S_{0} \subseteq S_{1}$, by 17.(a), $C$ is not a member of $\mathcal{F}_{0}$. This implies that $N_{G}(U) \cap V(C)=\emptyset$, and thus, $C \in \mathcal{C}_{0}$. In particular, $F$ is disjoint from $U^{\prime}$, and so, $F \in \mathcal{F}^{\prime}$. By (b'), $V(F) \cap S^{\prime} \neq \emptyset$, hence, there exists $i \in\left\{2, \ldots, \ell^{\prime}\right\}$ such that $V(F)$ intersects $W_{i-1}^{\prime} \cap W_{i}^{\prime}$. It follows that $W_{i-1}^{\prime} \cap W_{i}^{\prime}=W_{i} \cap W_{i+1}$ and so $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$. This proves (b).

Let us pause to underline a simple observation that follows directly from the construction, (a'), and ( $\left.\mathrm{f}^{\prime}\right)$ :

$(\star)$ for every $i \in\{3, \ldots, \ell\}$, we have $W_{i-1} \cap W_{i}=W_{i-2}^{\prime} \cap W_{i-1}^{\prime}$.
By (c'), $S^{\prime}=U^{\prime} \cup \bigcup_{i \in\{2, \ldots, \ell^{\prime}\}}\left(W_{i-1}^{\prime} \cap W_{i}^{\prime}\right)$ induces a connected subgraph of $G$. In particular, every component of $G\left[S^{\prime}\right]-U^{\prime}$ has a neighbor in $N_{G}\left(V(G)-U^{\prime}\right) \subseteq S_{1}$. Since $G\left[U \cup S_{1}\right]$ is connected, it follows that $\left(S^{\prime}-U^{\prime}\right) \cup U \cup S_{1}$ induces a connected subgraph of $G$. However, $S=\left(S^{\prime}-U^{\prime}\right) \cup U \cup S_{1}$ by $(\star)$, which yields (c).

For every $i \in\{3, \ldots, \ell\}, R_{i}=R_{i-1}^{\prime}$ induces a connected subgraph of $G$ by (d'), and $R_{2}=S_{1}$ induces a connected subgraph of $G$ by definition, hence (d) follows.

For the proof of (e), first, observe that by construction, $\bigcup_{j \in\{0, \ldots, i-1\}} W_{j}=\bigcup_{j \in\{0, \ldots, i-2\}} W_{j}^{\prime}$ for every $i \in\{2, \ldots, \ell\}$. In particular, it follows that $R_{i}=R_{i-1}^{\prime} \subseteq \bigcup_{j \in\{0, \ldots, i-2\}} W_{j}^{\prime}=$ $\bigcup_{j \in\{0, \ldots, i-1\}} W_{j}$ for every $i \in\{3, \ldots, \ell\}$ by (e'). Moreover, $R_{2}=S_{1} \subseteq W_{1}$. It remains to show that $W_{i-1} \cap W_{i} \subseteq R_{i}$ for every $i \in\{2, \ldots, \ell^{\prime}\}$. For $i=2, W_{1} \cap W_{2}=S_{1}-U \subseteq R_{2}$. For $i \in\{3, \ldots, \ell\}, W_{i-1} \cap W_{i}=W_{i-2}^{\prime} \cap W_{i-1}^{\prime} \subseteq R_{i-1}^{\prime}=R_{i}^{\prime}$ by ( $\star$ ) and ( $\left.\mathrm{e}^{\prime}\right)$. This gives (e).

For every $i \in\{3, \ldots, \ell-2\}, W_{i} \cap W_{i+2}=W_{i-1}^{\prime} \cap W_{i+1}^{\prime}=\emptyset$ by ( $\left.\mathrm{f}^{\prime}\right)$. Moreover, $W_{3}^{\prime}=W_{4}$ is disjoint from $S_{1}-U \subseteq W_{0}^{\prime}$ by (f'). Hence $W_{2} \cap W_{4}=W_{1}^{\prime} \cap W_{3}^{\prime}=\emptyset$ by (f'). Similarly, $W_{2}^{\prime}=W_{3}$ is disjoint from $U^{\prime}=W_{0}^{\prime}$ by (f'). Hence $W_{1} \cap W_{3}=W_{0}^{\prime} \cap W_{2}^{\prime}=\emptyset$. Finally, $W_{0} \cap W_{2}=\emptyset$ by construction, and so, (f) holds.

It remains to show (g). First, for every $i \in\{3, \ldots, \ell\}, R_{i}=R_{i-1}^{\prime}$ and so $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, R_{i}\right) \leqslant$ $(\delta(k, d+1)+3) \cdot r$ for every positive integer $r$ by ( $\left.\mathrm{g}^{\prime}\right)$. Moreover, $R_{2}=S_{1}=V(Q) \cup S_{0}$. Hence

$$
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, R_{2}\right) \leqslant \delta(k, d+1) \cdot r+(2 r+1) \leqslant(\delta(k, d+1)+3) \cdot r
$$

for every positive integer $r$, using 17.(c) and Observation 13. This shows that (g) holds, which concludes the proof of the lemma.

Now we are ready to prove Theorem 8 for graphs with no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of a fixed star. This part of the argument follows ideas from the proof by [13] that $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(P) \leqslant 2+\lceil\log r\rceil$ for every path $P$ and every positive integer $r$ - we explain the idea of this proof in Figure 10.

Lemma 31. Let $k, d$ be positive integers. For every connected $K_{k}$-minor-free graph $G$, for every family $\mathcal{F}$ of connected subgraphs of $G$, if $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $F_{2, d}$, then there is a set $S \subseteq V(G)$ such that
(a) $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$;
(b) $G[S]$ is connected;
(c) $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) \leqslant 5(\delta(k, d+1)+3) \cdot r \log r$ for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$.

Proof. Let $G$ be a connected $K_{k}$-minor-free graph, let $\mathcal{F}$ be a family of connected subgraphs of $G$, and suppose that $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $F_{2, d}$. Let $r$ be an integer with $r \geqslant 2$. Let $U$ be an arbitrary singleton of a vertex in $G$. Lemma 30 applied to $G, \mathcal{F}$, and $U$ gives a path decomposition $\left(W_{0}, \ldots, W_{\ell}\right)$ and sets $R_{2}, \ldots, R_{\ell} \subseteq V(G)$ such that for $S^{\prime}=U \cup$ $\bigcup_{i \in\{2, \ldots, \ell\}}\left(W_{i-1} \cap W_{i}\right)$
30.(a) $W_{0}=U$;
30.(b) $V(F) \cap S^{\prime} \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$;
30.(c) $G\left[S^{\prime}\right]$ is connected;
30.(d) $G\left[R_{i}\right]$ is connected for every $i \in\{1, \ldots, \ell\}$;
30.(e) $W_{i-1} \cap W_{i} \subseteq R_{i} \subseteq \bigcup_{j \in\{0, \ldots, i-1\}} W_{j}$ for every $i \in\{2, \ldots, \ell\}$;
30.(f) $W_{i}$ and $W_{i+2}$ are disjoint for every $i \in\{0, \ldots, \ell-2\}$; and
30.(g) $\operatorname{wcol}_{e}\left(G, R_{i}\right) \leqslant(\delta(k, d+1)+3) \cdot r$ for every $i \in\{2, \ldots, \ell\}$.

![img-9.jpeg](img-9.jpeg)

Figure 10. Consider the path $P=p_{1} \cdots p_{22}$. Let $r=7$ and $s=3=\lceil\log r\rceil$. We claim that $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(P) \leqslant 2+s$. We mark every eighth vertex with 3 (this corresponds to the set $I_{3}$ in the proof of Lemma 31). Then, we mark each fourth unmarked vertex with 2 (the set $I_{2}-I_{3}$ ), every second unmarked vertex with 1 (the set $I_{1}-I_{2}$ ), and finally all remaining vertices with 0 (the set $I_{0}-I_{1}$ ). Next, we construct an ordering on the vertices $p_{1}, \ldots, p_{22}$. First, preserving the original ordering in the path, we put the vertices marked with 3 , then similarly the ones marked with 2 , with 1 , and with 0 . It suffices to argue that for every $u \in V(P)$, we have $\mid \mathrm{WReach}_{r}[P, \sigma, u] \mid \leqslant 5$. We build an auxiliary tree (depicted in green in the figure), where for every $i \in\{3,2,1\}$, we connect every vertex marked with $i$ with the closest vertices in the path marked with $i-1$. It is not hard to see that $\mathrm{WReach}_{r}[P, \sigma, u]$ consists only of the ancestors of $u$ in the auxiliary tree.

For convenience, we set $R_{1}=U$.
Let $s=\lceil\log (r+1)\rceil$. For every $i \in\{0, \ldots, s\}$, let $I_{i}=\left\{i \in\{1, \ldots, \ell\} \mid j=0 \bmod 2^{i}\right\}$. We construct recursively families $\left\{R_{j}^{i}\right\}_{j \in\{1, \ldots, \ell\}}$ and $\left\{S_{i}\right\}_{i \in\{0, \ldots, s\}}$ of subsets of $V(G)$ and a family $\left\{\sigma_{j}\right\}_{j \in\{1, \ldots, \ell\}}$ such that $\sigma_{j}$ is an ordering of $R_{j}^{\prime}$ for every $j \in\{1, \ldots, \ell\}$. For every $j \in I_{s}$, let

$$
R_{j}^{\prime}=R_{j}-\bigcup_{a \in\left\{0, \ldots, j-2^{s}-1\right\}} W_{a}
$$

and let $S_{s}=\bigcup_{j \in I_{s}} R_{j}^{\prime}$. Let $j \in I_{s}$. If $j<2 \cdot 2^{s}$, then $j=2^{s}$ and $R_{j}^{\prime}=R_{j}$, and so by 30.(g), $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, R_{j}^{\prime}\right) \leqslant(\delta(k, d+1)+3) \cdot r$. Now assume that $j \geqslant 2 \cdot 2^{s}$. Since $\left(W_{0}, \ldots, W_{\ell}\right)$ is a path decomposition of $G, W_{j-2^{s}-1} \cap W_{j-2^{s}}$ separates $\bigcup_{a \in\left\{0, \ldots, j-2^{s}-1\right\}} W_{a}$ and $\bigcup_{a \in\left\{j-2^{s}, \ldots, \ell\right\}} W_{a}$ in $G$. Since $W_{j-2^{s}-1} \cap W_{j-2^{s}} \subseteq R_{j-2^{s}}^{\prime}$ (by 30.(e)), by Observation 10, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G-\bigcup_{a \in\left\{1, \ldots, j-2^{s}\right\} \cap I_{s}} R_{a}^{\prime}, R_{j}^{\prime}\right) & =\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G-\left(W_{j-2^{s}-1} \cap W_{j-2^{s}}\right), R_{j}^{\prime}\right) \\
& =\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G-\bigcup_{a \in\left\{0, \ldots, j-2^{s}-1\right\}} W_{a}, R_{j}^{\prime}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G-\bigcup_{a \in\left\{0, \ldots, j-2^{s}-1\right\}} W_{a}, R_{j}^{\prime}\right) & \leqslant \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, R_{j}\right) & & \text { by Observation } 14 \\
& \leqslant(\delta(k, d+1)+3) \cdot r & & \text { by 30.(g). }
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $\sigma_{j}$ be an ordering of $R_{j}^{\prime}$ such that

$$
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G-\bigcup_{a \in\left\{1, \ldots, j-2^{s}\right\} \cap I_{s}} R_{a}^{\prime}, R_{j}^{\prime}, \sigma_{j}\right) \leqslant(\delta(k, d+1)+3) \cdot r
$$

Next, let $i \in\{0, \ldots, s-1\}$ and assume that $S_{i+1}$ is defined. Now, for every $j \in I_{i}-I_{i+1}$, let

$$
R_{j}^{\prime}=\left(R_{j}-\bigcup_{a \in\left\{0, \ldots, j-2^{i}-1\right\}} W_{a}\right)-S_{i+1}
$$

and let $S_{i}=\bigcup_{j \in I_{i}} R_{j}^{\prime}$. Note that $S_{i+1} \subseteq S_{i}$. Also note that for every $j \in I_{i}, W_{j-1} \cap W_{j} \subseteq R_{j}^{\prime}$ by 30.(f). Let $j \in I_{i}-I_{i+1}$. We have $j-2^{i} \in I_{i+1}$, and therefore, $W_{j-2^{i}-1} \cap W_{j-2^{i}} \subseteq$ $R_{j-2^{i}}^{\prime} \subseteq S_{i+1}$. Since $\left(W_{0}, \ldots, W_{\ell}\right)$ is a path decomposition of $G, W_{j-2^{i}-1} \cap W_{j-2^{i}}$ separates $\bigcup_{a \in\left\{0, \ldots, j-2^{i}-1\right\}} W_{a}$ and $\bigcup_{a \in\left\{j-2^{i}, \ldots, \ell\right\}} W_{a}$ in $G$. It follows by Observation 10 that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G-S_{i+1}, R_{j}^{\prime}\right) & =\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G-\left(W_{j-2^{i}-1} \cap W_{j-2^{i}}\right), R_{j}^{\prime}\right) \\
& =\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G-\bigcup_{a \in\left\{0, \ldots, j-2^{i}-1\right\}} W_{a}, R_{j}^{\prime}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Furthermore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G-\bigcup_{a \in\left\{0, \ldots, j-2^{i}-1\right\}} W_{a}, R_{j}^{\prime}\right) & \leqslant \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, R_{j}\right) & & \text { by Observation } 14 \\
& \leqslant(\delta(k, d+1)+3) \cdot r & & \text { by 30.(g). }
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $\sigma_{j}$ be an ordering of $R_{j}^{\prime}$ such that

$$
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G-S_{i+1}, R_{j}^{\prime}, \sigma_{j}\right) \leqslant(\delta(k, d+1)+3) \cdot r
$$

We define $S=S_{0}$. Now, it suffices to show that (a)-(c) hold. Since $S^{\prime} \subseteq S$, (a) holds by 30.(b).
Recall that $G\left[S^{\prime}\right]$ is connected by 30.(c). Next, let $C$ be a component of $G\left[R_{j}^{\prime}\right]$ for some fixed $j \in I_{s}$. If $V(C) \cap\left(W_{j-1} \cap W_{j}\right) \neq \emptyset$, then $V(C) \cap S^{\prime} \neq \emptyset$, and so, $G\left[S^{\prime} \cup V(C)\right]$ is connected. Thus, assume that $V(C) \cap\left(W_{j-1} \cap W_{j}\right)=\emptyset$. However, $W_{j-1} \cap W_{j} \subseteq R_{j}^{\prime}$, hence, $C$ has a neighbor in $W_{j-2^{s}-1}$, in particular, in $W_{j-2^{s}-1} \cap W_{j-2^{s}} \subseteq S^{\prime}$. Hence, again $G\left[S^{\prime} \cup V(C)\right]$ is connected. In particular, we have just proved that $G\left[S^{\prime} \cup S_{s}\right]$ is connected. Next, suppose that $G\left[S^{\prime} \cup S_{i+1}\right]$ is connected for some $i \in\{0, \ldots, s-1\}$. Let $C$ be a component of $G\left[R_{j}^{\prime}\right]$ for some fixed $j \in I_{i}$. If $V(C) \cap\left(W_{j-1} \cap W_{j}\right) \neq \emptyset$, then $V(C) \cap S^{\prime} \neq \emptyset$, and so, $G\left[S^{\prime} \cup V(C)\right]$ is connected. Thus, assume that $V(C) \cap\left(W_{j-1} \cap W_{j}\right)=\emptyset$. However, $W_{j-1} \cap W_{j} \subseteq R_{j}^{\prime}$, hence, $C$ has a neighbor in $W_{j-2^{i}-1} \cup S_{i+1}$, in particular, in $\left(W_{j-2^{i}-1} \cap W_{j-2^{i}}\right) \cup S_{i+1} \subseteq S^{\prime} \cup S_{i+1}$. Hence, $G\left[S^{\prime} \cup S_{i+1} \cup V(C)\right]$ is connected. Finally, $G\left[S^{\prime} \cup S_{0}\right]=G[S]$ is connected, which yields (b).

The sets $\left\{R_{j}^{\prime}\right\}_{j \in\{2, \ldots, \ell\}}$ are pairwise disjoint, and they partition $S$. Let $\sigma$ be an ordering of $S$ such that
(i) $\sigma$ extends $\sigma_{j}$, for every $j \in\{1, \ldots, \ell\}$;
(ii) for every $j, j^{\prime} \in I_{s}$ with $j<j^{\prime}$, for all $u \in R_{j}^{\prime}$ and $v \in R_{j^{\prime}}^{\prime}, u<_{\sigma} v$; and
(iii) for every $i \in\{0, \ldots, s-1\}$, for all $u \in S_{i+1}$ and $v \in S_{i}-S_{i+1}, u<_{\sigma} v$.

Note the similarity of this ordering to the one described in Figure 10. For convenience, let $R_{0}^{\prime}=\emptyset$ and $W_{j}=R_{j}^{\prime}=\emptyset$ for every integer $j$ with $j>\ell$.

We now show (c). Let $u \in V(G)$. We will show that $\mid \mathrm{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u] \mid \leqslant 5(\delta(k, d+1)+$ $3) \cdot r \log r$. Let $j_{u} \in\{0, \ldots, \ell\}$ be minimum such that $u \in W_{j_{u}}$.

We claim that

$$
\left|\mathrm{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u] \cap S_{s}\right| \leqslant 2(\delta(k, d+1)+3) \cdot r
$$

Let $\alpha=\max \{0\} \cup\left\{a \in I_{s} \mid a \leqslant j_{u}\right\}$, and let $\beta=\alpha+2^{s}$. Thus, if $\beta \leqslant \ell$, then $\beta \in I_{s}$. Next, we argue that

$$
\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u] \cap S_{s} \subseteq R_{\alpha}^{\prime} \cup R_{\beta}^{\prime}
$$

Suppose to the contrary that there is a vertex $v \in \mathrm{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u] \cap S_{s}$ with $v \notin R_{\alpha}^{\prime} \cup R_{\beta}^{\prime}$. Let $\gamma \in I_{s}-\{\alpha, \beta\}$ be such that $v \in R_{\gamma}^{\prime}$. Then either $\gamma<\alpha$, or $\gamma>\beta$. First assume that $\gamma<\alpha$. Since $R_{\gamma}^{\prime} \subseteq \bigcup_{a \in\{0, \ldots, \gamma-1\}} W_{a}$ and because $\left(W_{0}, \ldots, W_{\ell}\right)$ is a path decomposition of $G$, every $u-v$ path in $G$ intersects $W_{a-1} \cap W_{a}$ for each $a \in\left\{\gamma, \ldots, j_{u}\right\}$. Since $\left(W_{a-1} \cap W_{a}\right)_{a \in\{1, \ldots, \ell\}}$ are pairwise disjoint, we deduce that $\operatorname{dist}_{G}(u, v) \geqslant j_{u}-\gamma \geqslant \alpha-\gamma \geqslant 2^{s}>r$, which contradicts the fact that $v \in \operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u]$. Finally, assume $\gamma>\beta$. Note that $\gamma \leqslant \ell$ since $R_{\gamma}^{\prime} \neq \emptyset$ as $v \in R_{\gamma}^{\prime}$. Since $R_{\gamma}^{\prime} \subseteq \bigcup_{a \in\left\{\gamma-2^{s}, \ldots, \gamma-1\right\}} W_{a}$, and because $\left(W_{0}, \ldots, W_{\ell}\right)$ is a path decomposition of $G$, every $u-v$ path in $G$ intersects $W_{\beta-1} \cap W_{\beta}$. However, for every $w \in W_{\beta-1} \cap W_{\beta}$, we have $w<_{\sigma} v$, thus, $v \notin \operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u]$, which is a contradiction. We obtain that $\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u] \cap S_{s} \subseteq R_{\alpha}^{\prime} \cup R_{\beta}^{\prime}$.

For every $\varepsilon \in\{\alpha, \beta\}$, by definition of $\sigma$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u] \cap R_{\varepsilon}^{\prime} & \subseteq \operatorname{WReach}_{r}\left[G-\bigcup_{a \in I_{s} \cap\{1, \ldots, \alpha-1\}} R_{a}^{\prime}, R_{\varepsilon}^{\prime}, \sigma_{\varepsilon}, u\right] \\
& \subseteq \operatorname{WReach}_{r}\left[G-\bigcup_{a \in\left\{1, \ldots, j_{u}-2^{s}\right\} \cap I_{s}} R_{a}^{\prime}, R_{\varepsilon}^{\prime}, \sigma_{\varepsilon}, u\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

and therefore,

$$
\left|\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u] \cap R_{\varepsilon}^{\prime}\right| \leqslant(\delta(k, d+1)+3) \cdot r
$$

In particular,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u] \cap S_{s}\right| & \leqslant\left|\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u] \cap\left(R_{\alpha}^{\prime} \cup R_{\beta}^{\prime}\right)\right| \\
& \leqslant 2(\delta(k, d+1)+3) \cdot r
\end{aligned}
$$

Next, let $i \in\{0, \ldots, s-1\}$. We claim that

$$
\left|\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u] \cap\left(S_{i}-S_{i+1}\right)\right| \leqslant(\delta(k, d+1)+3) \cdot r
$$

Since each vertex of $S_{i+1}$ precedes each vertex of $S_{i}$ in $\sigma$, we have
$\operatorname{WReach}_{r}\left[G, S, \sigma, u\right] \cap\left(S_{i}-S_{i+1}\right) \subseteq \operatorname{WReach}_{r}\left[G-S_{i+1}, S-S_{i+1},\left.\sigma\right|_{S-S_{i+1}}, u\right] \cap\left(S_{i}-S_{i+1}\right)$.
Let $\alpha=\max \left\{a \in I_{i+1} \mid a \leqslant j_{u}\right\}$ and $\beta=\alpha+2^{i+1}$. Let $C$ be the component of $u$ in $G-S_{i+1}$. Since $W_{\alpha-1} \cap W_{\alpha}, W_{\beta-1} \cap W_{\beta} \subseteq S_{i+1}$, and because $\left(W_{0}, \ldots, W_{\ell}\right)$ is a path decomposition of $G, V(C) \cap S \subseteq \bigcup_{a \in\{\alpha, \ldots, \beta-1\}} W_{a}$. We deduce that

$$
\operatorname{WReach}_{r}\left[G-S_{i+1}, S-S_{i+1},\left.\sigma\right|_{S-S_{i+1}}, u\right] \cap\left(S_{i}-S_{i+1}\right) \subseteq \bigcup_{a \in\{\alpha, \ldots, \beta-1\}} W_{a}
$$

Since the only members of $I_{i}-I_{i+1}$ in $\{\alpha+1, \ldots, \beta-1\}$ is $\gamma=\alpha+2^{i}$, we in fact have

$$
\operatorname{WReach}_{r}\left[G-S_{i+1}, S-S_{i+1},\left.\sigma\right|_{S-S_{i+1}}, u\right] \cap\left(S_{i}-S_{i+1}\right) \subseteq R_{\gamma}^{\prime}
$$

and we deduce that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\operatorname{WReach}_{r}\left[G-S_{i+1}, S-S_{i+1},\left.\sigma\right|_{S-S_{i+1}}, u\right] \cap\left(S_{i}-S_{i+1}\right)\right| & \leqslant \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G-S_{i+1}, R_{\gamma}^{\prime}, \sigma_{\gamma}\right) \\
& \leqslant(\delta(k, d+1)+3) \cdot r
\end{aligned}
$$

For convenience let $S_{s+1}=\emptyset$. Since $S=S_{0}$, it follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u]\right| & \leqslant \sum_{i \in\{0, \ldots, s\}}\left|\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u] \cap\left(S_{i}-S_{i+1}\right)\right| \\
& \leqslant(s+2) \cdot(\delta(k, d+1)+3) \cdot r \\
& \leqslant 5(\delta(k, d+1)+3) \cdot r \log r
\end{aligned}
$$

To generalize Lemma 31 to graphs with no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $F_{h, d}$ for $h>2$, we need the following straightforward property.

Lemma 32. Let $h, d$ be positive integers. Let $G$ be a connected graph. If there is a model $\left(B_{x} \mid\right.$ $\left.x \in V\left(F_{h, d+1}\right)\right)$ of $F_{h, d+1}$ in $G$, then for every $u \in V(G)$, there is a model $\left(B_{x}^{\prime} \mid x \in V\left(F_{h, d}\right)\right)$ of $F_{h, d}$ in $G$ such that
(a) $u \in B_{s}^{\prime}$, where $s$ is the root of $F_{h, d}$, and
(b) for every $x \in V\left(F_{h, d}\right), B_{y} \subseteq B_{x}^{\prime}$ for some $y \in V\left(F_{h, d+1}\right)$.

Proof. Suppose that there is a model $\left(B_{x} \mid x \in V\left(F_{h, d+1}\right)\right)$ of $F_{h, d+1}$ in $G$. Since $G$ is connected, we can assume that $\bigcup_{x \in V\left(F_{h, d+1}\right)} B_{x}=V(G)$. Let $s_{0}$ be the root of $F_{h, d+1}$. There is a subtree $T^{\prime}$ of $F_{h, d+1}$ rooted in a child of $s_{0}$ such that $u \in \bigcup_{x \in V\left(T^{\prime}\right) \cup\left\{s_{0}\right\}} B_{x}$. Define $B_{x}^{\prime}=\bigcup_{x \in V\left(T^{\prime}\right) \cup\left\{s_{0}\right\}} B_{x}$ and $B_{x}^{\prime}=B_{x}$ for every $x \in V\left(F_{h, d+1}\right)-\left(\left\{s_{0}\right\} \cup V\left(T^{\prime}\right)\right)$. The collection $\left(B_{x}^{\prime} \mid x \in V\left(F_{h, d}\right)\right)$ is a model of $F_{h, d}$ in $G$ satisfying (a) and (b).

The following lemma is the case of Theorem 8 where $t=2$.
Lemma 33. Let $k, h, d$ be positive integers with $h \geqslant 2$. There is an integer $c_{0}(h, d, k)$ such that for every connected $K_{k}$-minor-free graph $G$, for every family $\mathcal{F}$ of connected subgraphs of $G$, if $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $F_{h, d}$, then there is a set $S \subseteq V(G)$ such that
(a) $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$;
(b) $G[S]$ is connected;
(c) $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) \leqslant c_{0}(h, d, k) \cdot r \log r$ for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$.

Proof. We proceed by induction on $h$. For $h=2$, the result is given by Lemma 31 setting $c_{0}(1, d, k)=5(\delta(k, d+1)+3)$. Next, assume $h>2$ and that $c_{0}(h-1, d, k)$ witnesses the assertion for $h-1$. Let $c_{0}(h, d, k)=5(\delta(k, d+1)+3)+3+c_{0}(h-1, d+1, k)$.

Let $G$ be a connected $K_{k}$-minor-free graph and let $\mathcal{F}$ be a family of connected subgraphs of $G$. Suppose that $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $F_{h, d}$. Let $r$ be an integer with $r \geqslant 2$. Let $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ be the family of all the connected subgraphs $H$ of $G$ such that $H$ contains an $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{H}$-rich model of $F_{h-1, d+1}$. We claim that there is no $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$-rich model of $F_{2, d}$ in $G$. Suppose to the contrary that $\left(B_{x} \mid x \in V\left(F_{2, d}\right)\right)$ is such a model. Let $s$ be the root of $F_{2, d}$ and let $s^{\prime}$ be the root of $F_{h-1, d}$. For every $x \in V\left(F_{2, d}\right)-\{s\}$, by Lemma 32 , there is an $\mathcal{F}$-rich model $\left(C_{y} \mid y \in V\left(F_{h-1, d}\right)\right)$ of $F_{h-1, d}$ in $G\left[B_{x}\right]$ such that $C_{s^{\prime}}$ contains a vertex of $N_{G}\left(B_{s}\right) \cap B_{x}$. The union of these models together with $B_{s}$ yields an $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $F_{h, d}$ in $G$, which is a contradiction. See Figure 11.

Since $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$-rich model of $F_{2, d}$, by Lemma 31 , there is a set $S_{0} \subseteq V(G)$ such that
31.(a) for every $F \in \mathcal{F}^{\prime}, V(F) \cap S_{0} \neq \emptyset$;
31.(b) $G\left[S_{0}\right]$ is connected;
31.(c) $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, S_{0}\right) \leqslant 5(\delta(k, d+1)+3) \cdot r \log r$.

![img-10.jpeg](img-10.jpeg)

Figure 11. We provide an example of the construction of an $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $F_{h, d}$ in $G$ assuming that there is an $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$-rich model of $F_{2, d}$ in $G$ in the case where $h=3$ and $d=2$. In green, we depict an $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$-rich model of $F_{2, d}=F_{2,2}$ in the graph. Each branch set contains an $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $F_{h-1, d+1}=F_{2,3}$. We depict these models in yellow and the red stars are the elements of $\mathcal{F}$. The obtained model of $F_{h, d}=F_{3,2}$ we depict in blue. Note that this model is $\mathcal{F}$-rich.

Let $C$ be a component of $G-S_{0}$. By 31.(a), $C \notin \mathcal{F}^{\prime}$, and so, $C$ has no $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{C}$-rich model of $F_{h-1, d+1}$. Therefore, by induction hypothesis, there is a set $S_{C} \subseteq V(C)$ such that
(a') $V(F) \cap S_{C} \neq \emptyset$ for every $\left.F \in \mathcal{F}\right|_{C}$;
(b') $C\left[S_{C}\right]$ is connected;
(c') $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(C, S_{C}\right) \leqslant c_{0}(h-1, d+1, k) \cdot r \log r$.
Let $Q_{C}$ be an $S_{C} \sim N_{G}\left(S_{0}\right)$ geodesic in $G$. In particular, $Q_{C}$ is a geodesic in $C$. Let $\mathcal{C}$ be the family of components of $G-S_{0}$ and let

$$
S=S_{0} \cup \bigcup_{C \in \mathcal{C}}\left(S_{C} \cup V\left(Q_{C}\right)\right)
$$

See Figure 12 for an illustration. We claim that (a)-(c) hold.
Let $F \in \mathcal{F}$. If $V(F) \cap S_{0}=\emptyset$, then $V(F) \subseteq V(C)$ for some component $C$ of $G-S_{0}$. In particular, $F \in \mathcal{F} \mid C$, and thus, by (a'), $V(F) \cap S_{C} \neq \emptyset$, which proves (a). The graph $G[S]$ is connected by construction, (b') and 31.(b), which yields (b). The following sequence of inequalities concludes the proof of (c) and the lemma:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) & \leqslant \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, S_{0}\right)+\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G-S_{0}, \bigcup_{C \in \mathcal{C}}\left(S_{C} \cup V\left(Q_{C}\right)\right)\right) & & \text { by Observation } 12 \\
& \leqslant \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, S_{0}\right)+\max _{C \in \mathcal{C}} \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(C, S_{C} \cup V\left(Q_{C}\right)\right) & & \text { by Observation } 11 \\
& \leqslant \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, S_{0}\right)+\max _{C \in \mathcal{C}} \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(C, S_{C}\right)+(2 r+1) & & \text { by Observation } 13 \\
& \leqslant 5(\delta(k, d+1)+3) \cdot r \log r+c_{0}(h-1, d+1, k) \cdot r \log r+3 r & & \text { by 31.(c) and (c') } \\
& \leqslant(5(\delta(k, d+1)+3)+c_{0}(h-1, d+1, k)+3) \cdot r \log r & & \\
& =c_{0}(h, d, k) \cdot r \log r
\end{aligned}
$$
