# 6. Proof of the main THEOREM 

In this section, we prove Theorem 5. As already mentioned, the proof is by induction, and in Section 5 we covered the base case. The induction statement is encapsulated in Theorem 8. Note that in order to obtain Theorem 5 as a corollary of Theorem 8 one has to apply it to each connected component of $G$ with $k=|V(X)|$ and with the family of all one-vertex subgraphs of $G$ as $\mathcal{F}$. Note that in such a case $S$ must be equal to $V(G)$.

Theorem 34 (Theorem 8 restated). Let $k$ and $t$ be positive integers with $t \geqslant 2$. Let $X$ be a graph with $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X) \leqslant t$. There exists an integer $c(t, X, k)$ such that for every connected $K_{k}$-minor-free graph $G$, for every family $\mathcal{F}$ of connected subgraphs of $G$, if $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $X$, then there exists $S \subseteq V(G)$ such that
(A) $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$;
(B) $G[S]$ is connected;
(C) $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) \leqslant c(t, X, k) \cdot r^{t-1} \log r$ for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$.

Proof. We proceed by induction on $t$. When $t=2$, by Observation 21, $X$ is a forest. Let $h, d$ be positive integers such that $X \subseteq F_{h, d}$, and let $c_{0}(h, d, k)$ be the constant given by Lemma 33. The assertion with $c(2, X, k)=c_{0}(h, d, k)$ follows by applying Lemma 33. Next, let $t \geqslant 3$, and assume that the result holds for $t-1$. We refer to this property as the main induction hypothesis.

Claim 1. Let $Y$ be a graph with $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(Y) \leqslant t-1$. There is an integer $c_{1}(t, Y, k)$ such that for every connected $K_{k}$-minor-free graph $G$, for every $u \in V(G)$, for every family $\mathcal{F}$ of connected subgraphs of $G$, if $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $K_{1} \oplus Y$, then there exist $S \subseteq V(G)$, a tree $T$ rooted in $s \in V(T)$, and a tree partition $\left(T,\left(P_{x} \mid x \in V(T)\right)\right)$ of $G[S]$ with $P_{s}=\{u\}$ such that
(a) $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$;
(b) $G[S]$ is connected;
(c) for every component $C$ of $G-S, N_{G}(V(C)) \subseteq P_{x} \cup P_{y}$ for some $x, y \in V(T)$ with either $x=y$ or $x y$ is an edge in $T$
(d) for every $x \in V(T)$,

$$
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G_{x}, P_{x}\right) \leqslant c_{1}(t, Y, k) \cdot r^{t-2} \log r
$$

for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$, where, for $T_{x}$ being the subtree of $T$ rooted in $x, G_{x}$ is the subgraph of $G$ induced by the union of $U_{x}=\bigcup_{y \in V\left(T_{x}\right)} P_{y}$ and all the vertex sets of the components of $G-S$ having a neighbor in $U_{x}$.

![img-12.jpeg](img-12.jpeg)

Figure 13. An illustration of the statement of Claim 1.
The statement of the claim is visualized in Figure 13.

Proof of the claim. Let $X^{\prime}=K_{1} \sqcup Y$ and let $c_{1}(t, Y, k)=c\left(t-1, X^{\prime}, k\right)+3$. We proceed by induction on $|V(G)|$. If $|V(G)|=1$, then since $c_{1}(t, Y, k) \geqslant 1$, the result holds. Next, suppose that $|V(G)|>1$.

First, assume that $G-\{u\}$ is not connected. Let $\mathcal{C}$ be the family of all the components of $G-$ $\{u\}$. Consider a component $C \in \mathcal{C}$. By induction hypothesis applied to $G_{C}=G[V(C) \cup\{u\}],$ $u$, and $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{G_{C}}$, there exist $S_{C} \subseteq V\left(G_{C}\right)$, a tree $T_{C}$ rooted in $s_{C} \in V\left(T_{C}\right)$, and a tree partition $\left(T_{C},\left(P_{C, x} \mid x \in V\left(T_{C}\right)\right)\right)$ of $S_{C}$ in $G_{C}$ with $P_{C, s_{C}}=\{u\}$ such that
(a') $V(F) \cap S_{C} \neq \emptyset$ for every $\left.F \in \mathcal{F}\right|_{G[V(C) \cup\{u\})}$
(b') $G\left[S_{C}\right]$ is connected;
(c') for every component $C^{\prime}$ of $G_{C}-S_{C}, N_{G_{C}}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right) \subseteq P_{C, x} \cup P_{C, y}$ for some $x, y \in V\left(T_{C}\right)$ and either $x=y$ or $x y$ is an edge in $T_{C}$;
(d') for every $x \in V\left(T_{C}\right)$,

$$
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G_{C, x}, P_{C, x}\right) \leqslant c_{1}(t, Y, k) \cdot r^{t-2} \log r
$$

for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$, where, for $T_{C, x}$ being the subtree of $T_{C}$ rooted in $x, G_{C, x}$ is the subgraph of $G_{C}$ induced by the union of $U_{C, x}=\bigcup_{y \in V\left(T_{C, x}\right)} P_{C, y}$ and all the vertex sets of the components of $G_{C}-S_{C}$ having a neighbor in $U_{C, x}$

Then let $S=\bigcup_{C \in \mathcal{C}} S_{C}$, let $T$ be the tree obtained from the disjoint union of all the $T_{C}$ for $C \in \mathcal{C}$ by identifying all the vertices in $\left\{s_{C} \mid C \in \mathcal{C}\right\}$ into a single vertex $s$. Finally, let $P_{s}=\{u\}$ and $P_{x}=P_{C, x}$ for every $C \in \mathcal{C}$ and $x \in V\left(T_{C}\right)-\left\{s_{C}\right\}$. Then we claim that (a)-(d) hold. Indeed, for every $F \in \mathcal{F}, F$ is connected so either $F$ is a subgraph of $G-\{u\}$ or $F$ contains $u$. In both cases, we see that $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$, so (a) holds. Item (b) holds as $u \in S_{C}$ and $G\left[S_{C}\right]$ is connected for all $C \in \mathcal{C}$. Item (c) holds as every component of $G-S$ is a component of $G_{C}-S_{C}$ for some $C \in \mathcal{C}$. Finally, for all $x \in V(T)$ with $x \neq s$ item (d) follows directly from (d') and the construction of $T$, while when $x=s$, $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G_{s}, P_{s}\right)=1$ for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$. From now on we assume that $G-\{u\}$ is connected.

Let $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ be the family of all the connected subgraphs $H$ of $G-\{u\}$ such that $u \in N_{G}(V(H))$ and $F \subseteq H$ for some $F \in \mathcal{F}$. We argue that there is no $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$-rich model of $X^{\prime}$ in $G-\{u\}$. Suppose by contradiction that it exists. Such a model would contain an $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $K_{1} \sqcup Y$ in $G-\{u\}$ such that every branch set is adjacent to $u$. By adding $u$ to the branch set corresponding to $K_{1}$ in $K_{1} \sqcup Y$, we obtain an $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $K_{1} \oplus Y$ in $G$, which is a contradiction. This proves that there is no $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$-rich model of $X^{\prime}$ in $G-\{u\}$.

Since $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(X^{\prime}\right) \leqslant \max \left\{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(Y), 1\right\} \leqslant t-1$, by the main induction hypothesis applied to $X^{\prime}, G-\{u\}$, and $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$, there exists a set $S_{0} \subseteq V(G-\{u\})$ such that
(A') $V(F) \cap S_{0} \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}^{\prime}$;
(B') $(G-\{u\})\left[S_{0}\right]$ is connected;
(C') $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G-\{u\}, S_{0}\right) \leqslant c\left(t-1, X^{\prime}, k\right) \cdot r^{t-2} \log r$ for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$.
By possibly adding an arbitrary vertex of $V(G-\{u\})$ to $S_{0}$, we can assume $S_{0} \neq \emptyset$. Let $Q$ be a $u$ - $S_{0}$ geodesic in $G$ and let $S_{1}=\left(S_{0} \cup V(Q)\right)-\{u\}$. Note that $G\left[\{u\} \cup S_{1}\right]$ is connected by (B').

Let $\mathcal{C}_{1}$ be the family of all the components $C$ of $G-\left(\{u\} \cup S_{1}\right)$ such that $N_{G}(u) \cap V(C)=\emptyset$. Consider $C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$. Since $G$ is connected and $u \notin N_{G}(V(C))$, there is an edge between $V(C)$ and $S_{1}$ in $G$. Let $G_{C}$ be obtained from $G\left[V(C) \cup S_{1}\right]$ by contracting $S_{1}$ into a single vertex $u_{C}$. Note that $\left|V\left(G_{C}\right)\right|<|V(G)|$ since $u \notin V\left(G_{C}\right)$. Since $G_{C}$ is a minor of $G, G_{C}$ has no $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{C}$-rich model of $K_{1} \oplus Y$. By induction hypothesis applied to $G_{C}, u_{C}$, and $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{C}$, there exist $S_{C} \subseteq V\left(G_{C}\right)$, a tree $T_{C}$ rooted in $s_{C} \in V\left(T_{C}\right)$, and a tree partition $\left(T_{C},\left(P_{C, x} \mid x \in V\left(T_{C}\right)\right)\right)$ of $S_{C}$ in $G_{C}$ with $P_{C, s_{C}}=\left\{u_{C}\right\}$ such that
(a") $V(F) \cap S_{C} \neq \emptyset$ for every $\left.F \in \mathcal{F}\right|_{C}$;
(b") $G_{C}\left[S_{C}\right]$ is connected;
(c") for every component $C^{\prime}$ of $G_{C}-S_{C}, N_{G_{C}}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right) \subseteq P_{C, x} \cup P_{C, y}$ for some $x, y \in V\left(T_{C}\right)$ and either $x=y$ or $x y$ is an edge in $T_{C}$;
(d") for every $x \in V\left(T_{C}\right)$,

$$
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G_{C, x}, P_{C, x}\right) \leqslant c_{1}(t, Y, k) \cdot r^{t-2} \log r
$$

for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$, where, for $T_{C, x}$ being the subtree of $T_{C}$ rooted in $x, G_{x}$ is the subgraph of $G$ induced by the union of $U_{x}=\bigcup_{y \in V\left(T_{x}\right)} P_{y}$ and all the vertex sets of the components of $G_{C}-S_{C}$ having a neighbor in $U_{x}$.

Let

$$
S=\{u\} \cup S_{1} \cup \bigcup_{C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left(S_{C}-\left\{u_{C}\right\}\right)
$$

Let $T$ be obtained from the disjoint union of $\left\{T_{C} \mid C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}\right\}$ by identifying the vertices $\left\{s_{C} \mid C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}\right\}$ into a new vertex $s^{\prime}$ and by adding a new vertex $s$ adjacent to $s^{\prime}$ in $T$. Let $P_{s}=\{u\}, P_{s^{\prime}}=S_{1}$, and for each $C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}, x \in V\left(T_{C}-\left\{s_{C}\right\}\right)$, let $P_{x}=P_{C, x}$. See Figure 14 for the illustration of this construction.

In order to conclude, we argue that $\left(T,\left(P_{x} \mid x \in V(T)\right)\right)$ is a tree partition of $G[S]$ and (a)-(d) hold.

Since for every $C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}, u \notin N_{G}(V(C))$, every edge in $G[S]$ containing $u$ has another endpoint in $S_{1}=P_{s^{\prime}}$. Consider an edge $v w$ in $G[S]$ such that $v \in S_{1}$ and $w \in S_{C}$ for some $C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$. Since $\left\{T_{C},\left(P_{C, x} \mid x \in V\left(T_{C}\right)\right)\right\}$ is a tree partition of $G_{C}\left[S_{C}\right]$ with $P_{C, s_{C}}=\left\{u_{C}\right\}$ and $u_{C}$ is the result of the contraction of $S_{1}$, we conclude that $w \in P_{x}$ for some $x \in V\left(T_{C}\right)$ such that $s^{\prime} x$ is an edge in $T$. Finally, for every edge $v w$ of $G[S]$ with $v, w \notin\{u\} \cup S_{1}, v w$ is an edge of $G\left[S_{C}-\left\{u_{C}\right\}\right]$ for some component $C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$, and so $v \in P_{C, x}$ and $w \in P_{C, y}$ for adjacent or identical vertices $v, w$ of $T_{C}$. Then $v \in P_{x}$ and $w \in P_{y}$. It follows that $\left(T,\left(P_{x} \mid x \in V(T)\right)\right)$ is a tree partition of $G[S]$.

Let $F \in \mathcal{F}$. If $V(F) \cap\left(\{u\} \cup S_{1}\right) \neq \emptyset$, then $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$. Otherwise, $F \subseteq G-\{u\}$ and $V(F) \cap S_{0}=\emptyset$, and therefore by (A'), $F \notin \mathcal{F}^{\prime}$, so in particular, $u \notin N_{G}(V(F))$. In this case, there is a component $C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ such that $F \in\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{C}$, thus, $V(F) \cap S_{C} \neq \emptyset$ by (a"). This proves (a).

![img-13.jpeg](img-13.jpeg)

Figure 14. An illustration of the construction of $S$ and its tree partition in the proof of Claim 1. Note that in the sketched case $\mathcal{C}_{1}=\left\{C_{1}, C_{2}\right\}$.

Item (b) holds since $G\left[\{u\} \cup S_{1}\right]$ is connected and for every $C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}, G_{C}\left[S_{C}\right]$ is connected by (b") and $u_{C} \in S_{C}$.

For every component $C^{\prime}$ of $G-S$, either $N_{G}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right) \subseteq\{u\} \cup S_{1}=P_{s} \cup P_{s^{\prime}}$, or $C^{\prime} \subseteq C$ for some $C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$. In the latter case, $C^{\prime}$ is a component of $G_{C}-S_{C}$, and $u \notin N_{G}(V(C))$. By (c"), there is $x, y \in V\left(T_{C}\right)$ such that $N_{G_{C}}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right) \subseteq P_{C, x} \cup P_{C, y}$, and thus, $N_{G}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right) \subseteq P_{x} \cup P_{y}$. This proves (c).

Finally, we argue (d). For every $x \in V(T)$, we denote by $T_{x}$ the subtree of $T$ rooted in $x$, and by $U_{x}$ the subgraph of $G$ induced by $U_{x}=\bigcup_{y \in V\left(T_{x}\right)} P_{y}$ with the vertex sets of all the components of $G-S$ having a neighbor in $U_{x}$. Let $r$ be an integer with $r \geqslant 2$ and let $x \in V(T)$. For $x=s,\left|P_{s}\right|=1$, thus the assertion is clear. For $x=s^{\prime}$, we have $G_{s^{\prime}}$ is a union of components of $G-\{u\}$. By (C'), $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G_{s^{\prime}}, S_{0}\right)=\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G-\{u\}, S_{0}\right) \leqslant c\left(t-1, X^{\prime}, k\right) \cdot r^{t-2} \log r$. Since $Q$ is a geodesic in $G$, by Observation 15,

$$
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G-\{u\}, S_{1}\right) \leqslant c\left(t-1, X^{\prime}, k\right) \cdot r^{t-2} \log r+(2 r+1) \leqslant c_{1}(t, Y, k) \cdot r^{t-2} \log r
$$

For $x \in V\left(T_{C}-\left\{s_{C}\right\}\right)$ for some $C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$, we have $T_{x}=T_{C, x}$, thus, the asserted inequality follows from ( $\left.\mathrm{d}^{\prime \prime}\right)$. This ends the proof of the claim.

Claim 1 yields the following less technical statement.
Claim 2. Let $Y$ be a graph with $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(Y) \leqslant t-1$. There is an integer $c_{2}(t, Y, k)$ such that for every connected $K_{k}$-minor-free graph $G$, for every family $\mathcal{F}$ of connected subgraphs of $G$, if $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $K_{1} \oplus Y$, then there exists $S \subseteq V(G)$ such that
(a) $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$;
(b) $G[S]$ is connected;
(c) $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) \leqslant c_{2}(t, Y, k) \cdot r^{t-1} \log r$ for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$.

Proof of the claim. Let $c_{2}(t, Y, k)=2 \cdot c_{1}(t, Y, k)$ and let $r$ be an integer with $r \geqslant 2$. We apply Claim 1 with an arbitrary vertex $u \in V(G)$ to obtain $S \subseteq V(G)$, a tree $T$ rooted in $s \in V(T)$, and a tree partition $\left(T,\left(P_{x} \mid x \in V(T)\right)\right)$ of $S$ in $G$ with $P_{s}=\{u\}$ such that
1.(a) $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$;
1.(b) $G[S]$ is connected;

1.(c) for every component $C$ of $G-S, N_{G}(V(C)) \subseteq P_{x} \cup P_{y}$ for some $x, y \in V(T)$ and either $x=y$ or $x y$ is an edge in $T$;
1.(d) for every $x \in V(T)$,

$$
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G_{x}, P_{x}\right) \leqslant c_{1}(t, Y, k) \cdot r^{t-2} \log r
$$

for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$, where, for $T_{x}$ being the subtree of $T$ rooted in $x$, the graph $G_{x}$ is the union of $U_{x}=\bigcup_{y \in V\left(T_{x}\right)} P_{y}$ with the vertex sets of all the components of $G-S$ having a neighbor in $U_{x}$.

Items (a) and (b) hold by 1.(a) and 1.(b) respectively. It suffices to prove (c).
For each $x \in V(T)$, let $\sigma_{x}$ be an ordering of $P_{x}$ witnessing 1.(d) and let $\sigma^{\prime}=\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{|V(T)|}\right)$ be an elimination ordering of $T$. Finally, let $\sigma$ be the concatenation of $\sigma_{x_{1}}, \ldots, \sigma_{x_{|V(T)|}}$ in this order.

Let $u \in V(G)$. To conclude the claim, we argue that

$$
\left|\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u]\right| \leqslant c_{2}(t, Y, k) \cdot r^{t-1} \log r
$$

Let $x_{u} \in V(T)$ be such that if $u \in S$, then $u \in P_{x_{u}}$, and otherwise, $x_{u}$ is the vertex of $T$ furthest to $s$ such that $P_{x_{u}}$ intersects $N_{G}(V(C))$, where $C$ is the component of $u$ in $G-S$. Let $A$ be the set of all the ancestors of $x_{u}$ in $T$ in distance at most $r$ from $x_{u}$. In particular, $|A| \leqslant r+1$. By Observation 19 and 1.(c),

$$
\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u] \subseteq \bigcup_{y \in A} P_{y}
$$

Let $y \in A$. Since $\sigma$ extends $\sigma_{y}$ and $x_{u} \in V\left(T_{y}\right)$, by 1.(d), we have

$$
\left|\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u] \cap P_{y}\right| \leqslant \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G_{y}, P_{y}\right) \leqslant c_{1}(t, Y, k) \cdot r^{t-2} \log r
$$

Summarizing,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u]\right| & =\sum_{y \in A}\left|\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u] \cap P_{y}\right| \\
& \leqslant(r+1) \cdot c_{1}(t, Y, k) \cdot r^{t-2} \log r \\
& \leqslant 2 r \cdot c_{1}(t, Y, k) \cdot r^{t-2} \log r=c_{2}(t, Y, k) \cdot r^{t-1} \log r
\end{aligned}
$$

This concludes the proof of (c), and the claim follows.
We now move on to the final step of the proof.
Claim 3. Let $Y$ be a graph with $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(Y) \leqslant t-1$ and let $h, d$ be positive integers. There exists an integer $c_{3}(Y, h, d, k)$ such that for every connected $K_{k}$-minor-free graph $G$ and for every family $\mathcal{F}$ of connected subgraphs of $G$, if $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $T_{h, d}^{\prime}(Y)^{0}$, then there exists $S \subseteq V(G)$ such that
(a) $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$;
(b) $G[S]$ is connected;
(c) $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) \leqslant c_{3}(Y, h, d, k) \cdot r^{t-1} \log r$ for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$.

Proof of the claim. We proceed by induction on $h$. When $h=1, T_{h, d}^{\prime}(Y)=K_{1} \oplus(Y \sqcup Y)$ and the result follows from the previous claim applied to $Y \sqcup Y$ (note that $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(Y \sqcup Y)=\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(Y) \leqslant$ $t-1)$ by setting $c_{3}(Y, 1, d, k)=c_{2}(t, Y \sqcup Y, k)$.

![img-14.jpeg](img-14.jpeg)

Figure 15. An illustration of the graph $K_{1} \oplus Z$.
Now assume that $h>1$ and that the result holds for $h-1$. Fix a copy of $Y \sqcup Y$. For each $y \in V(Y \sqcup Y)$ add $d$ vertices with $y$ as a unique neighbor. Furthermore, add $2 d$ isolated vertices. We call the obtained graph $Z$ - see Figure 15. To keep things in order, we write $V(Z)=V_{Y} \cup V_{Z}$, where $V_{Y}$ are the vertices of $Y \sqcup Y$ in $Z$ and $V_{Z}$ are all the added vertices. Let

$$
c_{3}(Y, h, d, k)=c_{2}(t, Z, k)+c_{3}(Z, h-1, d, k)+3
$$

By (r8) and (r4), $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(Z) \leqslant \max \left\{2, \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(Y)\right\} \leqslant t-1$ since $t \geqslant 3$.
Let $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ be the family of all the connected subgraphs $H$ of $G$ such that $H$ has an $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{H^{-}}$-rich model of $T_{h-1, d}^{\prime}(Y)$. We claim that there is no $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$-rich model of $K_{1} \oplus Z$ in $G$. Suppose to the contrary that such a model $\left(A_{y} \mid y \in V\left(K_{1} \oplus Z\right)\right)$ exists. Let $s$ be the vertex of $K_{1}$ in $K_{1} \oplus Z$. In particular, $V\left(K_{1} \oplus Z\right)=\{s\} \cup V_{Y} \cup V_{Z}$. For every vertex $z \in V_{Z}$, we define its parent in $K_{1} \oplus Z$ in the following way. Note that $z$ has at most one neighbor in $Z$. If $z$ has a neighbor in $Z$, then the neighbor is its parent and if $z$ is isolated in $Z$, then $s$ is its parent. Let $z \in V_{Z}$ with the parent $p_{z}$ and let $u_{z} \in A_{z}$ be such that there is an edge between $u_{z}$ and a vertex in $A_{p_{z}}$. Since the model is $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$-rich, $G\left[A_{z}\right]$ contains an $\mathcal{F}\left[G\left[A_{z}\right]^{-}\right.$-rich model of $T_{h-1, d}^{\prime}(Y)$. Let $H_{z}$ be a copy of $T_{h-1, d}(Y)$ with a root $s_{z}$. By Lemma 29 applied to $Y, G\left[A_{z}\right]$, and $u$, there is an $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{G\left[A_{z}\right]^{-}}$-rich model $\left(B_{z, x} \mid x \in V\left(H_{z}\right)\right)$ of $H_{z}$ in $G\left[A_{z}\right]$ such that $u_{z} \in B_{z, s_{z}}$. In particular, there is an edge between $B_{z, s_{z}}$ and $A_{p_{z}}$ in $G$. Finally, we construct an $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $T_{h, d}^{\prime}(Y)$ in $G$. Observe that the graph obtained from $\left(K_{1} \oplus Z\right)\left[\{s\} \cup V_{Y}\right]$ (this graph is isomorphic to $K_{1} \oplus(Y \sqcup Y))$ and the disjoint union of $H_{z}$ for each $z \in V_{Z}$ by identifying $s_{z} \in V\left(H_{z}\right)$ with $p_{z} \in\{s\} \cup V_{Y}$ for each $z \in V_{Z}$ is isomorphic to $T_{h, d}^{\prime}(Y)$. For each $p \in\{s\} \cup V_{Y}$, let $P_{y}$ be the set of all $z \in V_{Z}$ such that $p$ is the parent of $z$. Let
(i) $D_{p}=A_{p} \cup \bigcup_{z \in P_{y}} B_{z, s_{z}}$ for every $p \in\{s\} \cup V_{Y}$ and
(ii) $D_{x}=B_{z, x}$ for every $z \in V_{Z}$ and $x \in V\left(H_{z}-\left\{s_{z}\right\}\right)$.

It follows that $\left(D_{x} \mid x \in\{s\} \cup V_{Y} \cup \bigcup_{z \in V_{Z}} V\left(H_{z}-\left\{s_{z}\right\}\right)\right)$ is an $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $T_{h, d}^{\prime}(Y)$ in $G$. This is a contradiction, hence, $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$-rich model of $K_{1} \oplus Z$.

By Claim 2, applied to $Z, G$, and $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ there exists $S_{0} \subseteq V(G)$ such that
2.(a) $V(F) \cap S_{0} \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}^{\prime}$;
2.(b) $G\left[S_{0}\right]$ is connected;
2.(c) $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, S_{0}\right) \leqslant c_{2}(t, Z, k) \cdot r^{t-1} \log r$ for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$.

# 7. A TIGHTER BOUND FOR GRAPHS OF BOUNDED TREEWIDTH 

In this section, we prove Theorem 6 .
7.1. Preliminaries. We start by recalling the notion of tree decomposition and one of its basic properties. Then, we introduce a refined version of tree decomposition - natural tree decomposition. Let $G$ be a graph. A tree decomposition of a graph $G$ is a pair $\mathcal{D}=\left(T,\left(W_{x} \mid\right.\right.$ $x \in V(T))$ ) where $T$ is a tree and $W_{x} \subseteq V(G)$ for every $x \in V(T)$ satisfying the following conditions:
(i) for every $u \in V(G), T\left[\left\{x \in V(T) \mid u \in W_{x}\right\}\right]$ is a connected subtree of $T$, and
(ii) for every edge $u v \in E(G)$, there exists $x \in V(T)$ such that $u, v \in W_{x}$.

The sets $W_{x}$ are called bags of $\mathcal{D}$. The width of $\mathcal{D}$ is $\max _{x \in V(T)}\left|W_{x}\right|-1$, and the treewidth of $G$, denoted by $\operatorname{tw}(G)$, is the minimum width of a tree decomposition of $G .{ }^{10}$

Lemma 35 ([20, Statement (8.7)]). For every graph $G$, for every tree decomposition $\mathcal{D}$ of $G$, for every family $\mathcal{F}$ of connected subgraphs of $G$, for every positive integer $d$, either
(1) there are d pairwise vertex-disjoint subgraphs in $\mathcal{F}$ or
(2) there is a set $S$ that is the union of at most $d-1$ bags of $\mathcal{D}$ such that $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$.

A tree decomposition $\left(T,\left(W_{x} \mid x \in V(T)\right)\right)$ of a graph $G$ is natural if for every edge $e$ in $T$, for each component $T_{0}$ of $T-e$, the graph $G\left[\bigcup_{z \in V\left(T_{0}\right)} W_{z}\right]$ is connected. The following statement appeared first in [6], see also [7].

Lemma 36 ([6, Theorem 1]). Let $G$ be a connected graph and let $\left(T,\left(W_{x} \mid x \in V(T)\right)\right)$ be a tree decomposition of $G$. There exists a natural tree decomposition $\left(T^{\prime},\left(W_{x}^{\prime} \mid x \in V\left(T^{\prime}\right)\right)\right)$ of $G$ such that for every $x^{\prime} \in V\left(T^{\prime}\right)$ there is $x \in V(T)$ with $W_{x^{\prime}}^{\prime} \subseteq W_{x}$.

The following lemma is folklore. See e.g. [2, Lemma 8] for a proof.
Lemma 37. Let $m$ be a positive integer. Let $G$ be a graph and let $\mathcal{D}$ be a tree decomposition of $G$. If $Y$ is the union of $m$ bags of $\mathcal{D}$, then there is a set $X$ that is the union of at most $2 m-1$ bags of $\mathcal{D}$ such that $Y \subseteq X$ and for every component $C$ of $G-X, N_{G}(V(C)) \cap X$ is a subset of the union of at most two bags of $\mathcal{D}$. Moreover, if $\mathcal{D}$ is natural, then $N_{G}(V(C))$ intersects at most two components of $G-V(C)$.

We need the following technical statement. For a given set $S$, we say that a collection $S_{1}, \ldots, S_{k} \subseteq S$ is a covering of $S$ if $S_{1} \cup \cdots \cup S_{k}=S$.

There exists a graph $X^{\prime}$ such that $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(X^{\prime}\right) \leqslant \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X)$ and for each covering $S_{1}, \ldots, S_{k}$ of $V\left(X^{\prime}\right)$, there exists $i \in[k]$ such that $X^{\prime}$ contains an $\left\{H \subseteq X^{\prime} \mid H\right.$ connected and $\left.S_{i} \cap V(H) \neq \emptyset\right\}$-rich model of $X$.

This first lemma is a modification of a proof in [3, Lemma 8].
Lemma 40. Let $d$ be a positive integer. Let $G$ be a connected graph, let $\mathcal{D}=\left\{T,\left(W_{x} \mid x \in\right.\right.$ $V(T)))$ be a tree decomposition of $G$, and let $\mathcal{F}$ be a family of connected subgraphs of $G$ such that $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $F_{2, d}$. For every $u \in V(G)$, there is a set $S \subseteq V(G)$ and a layering $\left(P_{0}, \ldots, P_{\ell}\right)$ of $G[S]$ with $P_{0}=\{u\}$ such that
(a) $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$;
(b) for every component $C$ of $G-S, N_{G}(V(C)) \subseteq P_{i} \cup P_{j}$ for some $i, j \in\{0, \ldots, \ell\}$ and either $i=j$ or $j=i+1$;
(c) for every $i \in[\ell], P_{i}$ is contained in the union of at most $d$ bags of $\mathcal{D}$.

Proof. We illustrate some parts of the proof in Figure 17. We proceed by induction on $|V(G)|$. If $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{G-\{u\}}$ is empty, then it suffices to take $\ell=0$ and $P_{0}=\{u\}$. In particular, this is the case for $|V(G)|=1$. Therefore, assume $|V(G)|>1$ and $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{G-\{u\}} \neq \emptyset$. Let $\mathcal{F}_{0}$ be the family of all the connected subgraphs $A$ of $G-\{u\}$ such that $A$ contains some member of $\mathcal{F}$ and $V(A) \cap N_{G}(u) \neq \emptyset$. Since $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{G-\{u\}} \neq \emptyset$ and $G$ is connected, $\mathcal{F}_{0}$ is nonempty.

Observe that any collection of $d+1$ pairwise disjoint $A_{1}, \ldots, A_{d+1} \in \mathcal{F}_{0}$ yields an $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $F_{2, d}$ in $G$. Indeed, it suffices to take $\{u\} \cup A_{d+1}$ as the branch set corresponding to the root of $F_{2, d}$ and $A_{1}, \ldots, A_{d}$ as the branch sets of the remaining $d$ vertices of $F_{2, d}$. Therefore, there is at most $d$ pairwise disjoint members of $\mathcal{F}_{0}$, and thus, by Lemma 35 applied to $G-\{u\}$ and $\mathcal{F}_{0}$, there exists a set $Z \subseteq V(G-\{u\})$ included in the union of at most $d$ bags of $\mathcal{D}$ such that $Z \cap V(F) \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}_{0}$. Suppose that $Z$ is inclusion-wise minimal for this property. Note that since $\mathcal{F}_{0} \neq \emptyset, Z$ is nonempty.

Let $\mathcal{C}_{0}$ be the family of all the components $C$ of $G-(\{u\} \cup Z)$ such that $N_{G}(u) \cap V(C)=$ $\emptyset$. Let $W=\bigcup_{C \in \mathcal{C}_{0}} V(C)$. Let $z \in Z$. By the minimality of $Z$, there exists $A_{z} \in \mathcal{F}_{0}$ with $V\left(A_{z}\right) \cap(Z-z)=\emptyset$. We have $A_{z}-\{z\} \notin \mathcal{F}_{0}$, thus, $z \in V\left(A_{z}\right)$. Since $A_{z} \in \mathcal{F}_{0}$, $V\left(A_{z}\right) \cap N_{G}(u) \neq \emptyset$, and so, there is a $u-z$ path $Q_{z}$ in $G\left[\{u\} \cup A_{z}\right] \subseteq G-(Z-z)$. For every component $C \in \mathcal{C}_{0}$, we have $V(C) \cap V\left(Q_{z}\right)=\emptyset$, hence, $W \cap V\left(Q_{z}\right)=\emptyset$.

Let $Q=\bigcup_{z \in Z} V\left(Q_{z}\right)$ and let $G^{\prime}$ be the graph obtained from $G[W \cup Q]$ by contracting $Q$ into a single vertex $u^{\prime}$. Note that $G^{\prime}$ is a minor of $G$, and $V\left(G^{\prime}\right)=\left\{u^{\prime}\right\} \cup W$. Moreover, since $Z \neq \emptyset$, we have $\left|V\left(G^{\prime}\right)\right|<|V(G)|$.

This proves (b).

Finally, $P_{0}$ is contained in one bag of $\mathcal{D}, P_{1}$ is contained in at most $d$ bags of $\mathcal{D}$ by the definition of $Z$, and for every $i \in\{2, \ldots, \ell\}, P_{i}$ is contained in at most $d$ bags of $\mathcal{D}$ by (c'). Therefore, (c) holds, which concludes the proof of the lemma.

Recall that in the base case of the proof of Theorem 5 (see Section 5), we applied the ideas required to prove that positive integer $r$ and for every path $P, \operatorname{wcol}_{r}(P) \leqslant 2+\lceil\log r\rceil$. We

illustrated these ideas in Figure 10. In this section, it suffices to use this result as a black box. We state it here for reference.

Lemma 41 ([13]). For every positive integer $r$ and for every path $P, \operatorname{wcol}_{r}(P) \leqslant 2+\lceil\log r\rceil$.
Lemma 42. Let $k, d$ be positive integers. For every graph $G$, for every tree decomposition $\mathcal{D}$ of $G$ of width at most $k-1$, for every family $\mathcal{F}$ of connected subgraphs of $G$, if $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $F_{2, d}$, then there is a set $S \subseteq V(G)$ such that
(a) $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$;
(b) for every component $C$ of $G-S, N_{G}(V(C))$ is contained in the union of at most $2 d$ bags of $\mathcal{D}$;
(c) $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) \leqslant 6 d k \cdot \log r$ for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$.

Proof. Let $G$ be a graph, let $\mathcal{D}$ be a tree decomposition of $G$ of width at most $k-1$, let $\mathcal{F}$ be a family of connected subgraphs of $G$, and suppose that $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $F_{2, d}$. Let $r$ be an integer with $r \geqslant 2$. By considering the components of $G$ independently, we can assume that $G$ is connected. Let $u$ be an arbitrary vertex in $G$. Lemma 40 applied to $G, \mathcal{D}, \mathcal{F}$, and $u$ gives $S \subseteq V(G)$, a layering $\left(P_{0}, \ldots, P_{\ell}\right)$ of $G[S]$ with $P_{0}=\{u\}$ such that
40.(a) $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$;
40.(b) for every component $C$ of $G-S, N_{G}(V(C)) \subseteq P_{i} \cup P_{j}$ for some $i, j \in\{0, \ldots, \ell\}$ and either $i=j$ or $j=i+1$;
40.(c) for every $i \in[\ell], P_{i}$ is contained in the union of at most $d$ bags of $\mathcal{D}$.

Note that (a) holds by 40.(a) and (b) holds by 40.(b) and 40.(c). In order to conclude the proof, it suffices to show (c).

For convenience, let $P_{\ell+1}=\emptyset$. Consider the path $Q$ with $V(Q)=\{0, \ldots, \ell+1\}$ where two numbers are connected by an edge whenever they are consecutive. Let $\sigma^{\prime}=i_{0} \ldots i_{\ell}$ be an ordering of $\{0, \ldots, \ell+1\}$ given by Lemma 41, that is, $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(Q, \sigma^{\prime}\right) \leqslant 1+\lceil\log r\rceil \leqslant 3 \log r$. For each $i \in\{0, \ldots, \ell+1\}$, let $\sigma_{i}$ be an arbitrary ordering of $P_{i}$. Let $\sigma$ be the concatenation of $\sigma_{i_{0}} \ldots \sigma_{i_{\ell+1}}$ in this order.

Let $u \in V(G)$. To conclude the claim, we argue that

$$
\left|\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u]\right| \leqslant 6 d k \cdot \log r
$$

Let $i_{u} \in V(T)$ be such that if $u \in S$, then $u \in P_{i_{u}}$, and otherwise, $i_{u} \in\{0, \ldots, \ell\}$ is the least value such that $P_{i_{u}}$ intersects $N_{G}(C)$, where $C$ is the component of $u$ in $G-S$. Let $A=\operatorname{WReach}_{r}\left[Q, \sigma^{\prime}, i_{u}\right] \cup \operatorname{WReach}_{r}\left[Q, \sigma^{\prime}, i_{u}+1\right]$. In particular, $|A| \leqslant 2 \cdot \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(Q, \sigma^{\prime}\right) \leqslant 2 \cdot 3 \log r$ By 40.(b),

$$
\operatorname{WReach}[G, S, \sigma, u] \subseteq \bigcup_{j \in A} P_{j}
$$

By 40.(c), for every $j \in\{0, \ldots, \ell+1\}, P_{j}$ is contained in the union of at most $d$ bags of $\mathcal{D}$ and since the width of $\mathcal{D}$ is at most $k-1$, we have $\left|P_{j}\right| \leqslant d k$. It follows that

$$
|\operatorname{WReach}[G, S, \sigma, u]| \leqslant|A| \cdot d k \leqslant 6 d k \log r
$$

Lemma 43. Let $k, h, d$ be positive integers with $h \geqslant 2$. There is an integer $\bar{c}_{0}(h, d)$ such that for every graph $G$, for every tree decomposition $\mathcal{D}$ of $G$ of width at most $k-1$, for every family $\mathcal{F}$ of connected subgraphs of $G$, if $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $F_{h, d}$, then there is a set $S \subseteq V(G)$ such that
(a) $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$,

(b) for every component $C$ of $G-S, N_{G}(V(C))$ is contained in the union of at most $2 d(h-$ 1) $+2\binom{ h-1}{2}$ bags of $\mathcal{D}$
(c) $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) \leqslant \bar{c}_{0}(h, d) k \cdot \log r$ for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$.

Proof. We proceed by induction on $h$. For $h=2$, the result holds by Lemma 42 setting $\bar{c}_{0}(h, d)=6 d k$, since $2 d(2-1)+2\binom{ 2-1}{2}=2 d$. Next, assume $h \geqslant 3$ and that $\bar{c}_{0}(h, d)$ witnesses the assertion for $h-1$. Let $\bar{c}_{0}(h, d)=6 d+\bar{c}_{0}(h-1, d+1)$.

Let $G$ be a graph and let $\mathcal{D}$ be a tree decomposition of $G$ of width at most $k-1$. Let $\mathcal{F}$ be a family of connected subgraphs of $G$. Let $r$ be an integer with $r \geqslant 2$. Let $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ be the family of all the connected subgraphs $H$ of $G$ such that $H$ contains an $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{H}$-rich model of $F_{h-1, d+1}$. We claim that there is no $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$-rich model of $F_{2, d}$ in $G$. Suppose to the contrary that $\left(B_{x} \mid x \in V\left(F_{2, d}\right)\right)$ is such a model. Let $s$ be the root of $F_{2, d}$ and let $s^{\prime}$ be the root of $F_{h-1, d}$. For every $x \in V\left(F_{2, d}\right)-\{s\}$, by Lemma 32 , there is an $\mathcal{F}$-rich model $\left(C_{y} \mid y \in V\left(F_{h-1, d}\right)\right)$ of $F_{h-1, d}$ in $G\left[B_{x}\right]$ such that $C_{s^{\prime}}$ contains a vertex of $N_{G}\left(B_{s}\right) \cap B_{x}$. The union of these models together with $B_{s}$ yields an $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $F_{h, d}$ in $G$, which is a contradiction. Note that this is exactly the same argument as in Lemma 33, see Figure 11.

Since $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$-rich model of $F_{2, d}$, by Lemma 42 , there is a set $S_{0} \subseteq V(G)$ such that
42.(a) for every $F \in \mathcal{F}^{\prime}, V(F) \cap S_{0} \neq \emptyset$;
42.(b) for every component $C$ of $G-S_{0}, N_{G}(V(C))$ is contained in the union of at most $2 d$ bags of $\mathcal{D}$
42.(c) $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, S_{0}\right) \leqslant 6 d k \cdot \log r$.
Let $C$ be a component of $G-S_{0}$. Let $\mathcal{D}_{C}$ be $\mathcal{D}$ restricted to $C$. By 42.(a), $C \notin \mathcal{F}^{\prime}$, and so, $C$ has no $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{C}$-rich model of $F_{h-1, d+1}$. Therefore, by induction hypothesis, there is a set $S_{C} \subseteq V(C)$ such that
(a') $V(F) \cap S_{C} \neq \emptyset$ for every $\left.F \in \mathcal{F}\right|_{C}$;
(b') for every component $C^{\prime}$ of $C-S_{C}, N_{C}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right)$ is contained in the union of at most $2(d+1)(h-2)+2\binom{ h-2}{2}=2 d(h-1)+2\binom{ h-1}{2}-2 d$ bags of $\mathcal{D}_{C}$;
(c') $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(C, S_{C}\right) \leqslant \bar{c}_{0}(h-1, d+1) k \cdot \log r$.
Let $\mathcal{C}$ be the family of components of $G-S_{0}$ and let

$$
S=S_{0} \cup \bigcup_{C \in \mathcal{C}} S_{C}
$$

We claim that (a)-(c) hold. Let $F \in \mathcal{F}$. If $V(F) \cap S_{0}=\emptyset$, then $V(F) \subseteq V(C)$ for some component $C$ of $G-S_{0}$. In particular, $\left.F \in \mathcal{F}\right|_{C}$, and thus, by (a'), $V(F) \cap S_{C} \neq \emptyset$, which proves (a). For every component $C^{\prime}$ of $G-S$, there exists a component $C$ of $G-S_{0}$ such that $C^{\prime} \subseteq C$ and by 42.(b) and (b'), $N_{G}\left(C^{\prime}\right)$ is contained in at most $2 d+\left(2 d(h-1)+2\binom{ h-1}{2}-2 d\right)=$ $2 d(h-1)+2\binom{ h-1}{2}$ bags of $\mathcal{D}$, which implies (b).

The following sequence of inequalities concludes the proof of (c) and the lemma:

$$
\begin{array}{rlr}
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) & \leqslant \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, S_{0}\right)+\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G-S_{0}, \bigcup_{C \in \mathcal{C}} S_{C}\right) & \text { by Observation } 12 \\
& \leqslant \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, S_{0}\right)+\max _{C \in \mathcal{C}} \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(C, S_{C}\right) & \text { by Observation } 11 \\
& \leqslant 6 d k \cdot \log r+\bar{c}_{0}(h-1, d+1) k \cdot \log r & \text { by 42.(c) and (c') } \\
& =\bar{c}_{0}(h, d) k \cdot \log r &
\end{array}
$$

We now show that using Lemma 37, the constant $2 d(h-1)+2\binom{ h-1}{2}$ in (b) in Lemma 43 can be reduced to two.

Lemma 44. Let $k, h, d$ be positive integers with $h \geqslant 2$. For every graph $G$ with $\operatorname{tw}(G)<k$, for every family $\mathcal{F}$ of connected subgraphs of $G$, if $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $F_{h, d}$, then there is a set $S \subseteq V(G)$ such that
(a) $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$;
(b) for every component $C$ of $G-S, N_{G}(V(C))$ intersects at most two components of $G-V(C)$;
(c) $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) \leqslant\left(\bar{c}_{0}(h, d)+4 d h^{2}\right) k \cdot \log r$ for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$, where $\bar{c}_{0}(h, d)$ is the constant from Lemma 43.

Proof. Let $G$ be a graph and let $\mathcal{D}$ be a tree decomposition of $G$ of width at most $k-1$. We may assume $G$ is connected. By Lemma 36, we can assume that $\mathcal{D}$ is a natural tree decomposition of $G$. By Lemma 42 applies to $G, \mathcal{D}$, and $\mathcal{F}$, there is a set $S_{0} \subseteq V(G)$ such that
42.(a) $V(F) \cap S_{0} \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$,
42.(b) for every component $C$ of $G-S_{0}, N_{G}(V(C))$ is contained in the union of at most $2 d(h-1)+2\binom{ h-1}{2}$ bags of $\mathcal{D}$
42.(c) $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, S_{0}\right) \leqslant \bar{c}_{0}(h, d) k \cdot \log r$ for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$.

Let $C$ be a component of $G-S_{0}$. By 42.(b) and Lemma 37, there exists a family $\mathcal{B}_{C}$ of at most $2\left(2 d(h-1)+2\binom{ h-1}{2}\right)-1 \leqslant 4 d h^{2}$ bags of $\mathcal{D}$ such that $N_{G}(V(C)) \subseteq \bigcup \mathcal{B}_{C}$ and for every component $C^{\prime}$ of $G-\bigcup \mathcal{B}_{C}, N_{G}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right)$ intersects at most two components of $G-V\left(C^{\prime}\right)$. Let $S_{C}=V(C) \cap \bigcup \mathcal{B}_{C}$. Then, for every component $C^{\prime}$ of $G-\left(S_{0} \cup S_{C}\right)$ intersecting $V(C), C$ is a component of $G-\bigcup \mathcal{B}_{C}$, and so $N_{G}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right)$ intersects at most two component of $G-V\left(C^{\prime}\right)$.

Let $\mathcal{C}$ be the family of all the components of $G-S_{0}$ and let

$$
S=S_{0} \cup \bigcup_{C \in \mathcal{C}} S_{C}
$$

Item (b) follows from the previous considerations and (a) follows directly from 42.(a). Now, it suffices to justify (c). To this end, let $r$ be an integer with $r \geqslant 2$. Then,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) \leqslant \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, S_{0}\right)+\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G-S_{0}, \bigcup_{C \in \mathcal{C}} S_{C}\right) \quad \text { by Observation } 12 \\
& \leqslant \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, S_{0}\right)+\max _{C \in \mathcal{C}} \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(C, S_{C}\right) \quad \text { by Observation } 11 \\
& \leqslant \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, S_{0}\right)+\max _{C \in \mathcal{C}}\left|S_{C}\right| \\
& \leqslant \bar{c}_{0}(h, d) k \cdot \log r+4 d h^{2} k \quad \text { by } 42 .(\mathrm{c}) \\
& \leqslant\left(\bar{c}_{0}(h, d)+4 d h^{2}\right) k \cdot \log r
\end{aligned}
$$

7.3. Induction. We can now prove Theorem 6 in the following stronger version, which is very similar to Theorem 8, with a slightly relaxed condition (B). Note that the following proof and the one of Theorem 8 largely overlap, but since there is no non-artificial way to merge them, we elect to give full proofs of both theorems.

Theorem 45. Let $t$ be positive integers with $t \geqslant 2$. Let $X$ be a graph with $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X) \leqslant t$. There exist an integer $\bar{c}(t, X)$ such that for every integer $k$, for every graph $G$ with $\operatorname{tw}(G)<k$, for every family $\mathcal{F}$ of connected subgraphs of $G$, if $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $X$, then there exists $S \subseteq V(G)$ such that

(A) $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$;
(B) for every component $C$ of $G-S, N_{G}(V(C))$ intersects at most two components of $G-$ $V(C)$;
(C) $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) \leqslant \bar{c}(t, X) k \cdot r^{t-2} \log r$ for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$.

Proof. We proceed by induction on $t$. When $t=2$, by Observation 21, $X$ is a forest. Let $h, d$ be positive integers such that $X \subseteq F_{h, d}$, and let $\bar{c}_{0}(h, d)$ be the constant given by Lemma 44. The assertion with $\bar{c}(t, X)=\bar{c}_{0}(h, d)+4 d h^{2}$ follows by applying Lemma 44. Next, let $t \geqslant 3$, and assume that the result holds for $t-1$. We refer to this property as the main induction hypothesis.

Claim 4. Let $Y$ be a graph with $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(Y) \leqslant t-1$. There is an integer $\bar{c}_{1}(t, Y)$ such that for every positive integer $k$, for every connected graph $G$ with $\operatorname{tw}(G)<k$, for every nonempty set $U$ of vertices of $G$ with $|U| \leqslant 2$, for every family $\mathcal{F}$ of connected subgraphs of $G$, if $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $K_{1} \oplus Y$, then there exist $S \subseteq V(G)$, a tree $T$ rooted in $s \in V(T)$, and a tree partition $\left(T,\left(P_{x} \mid x \in V(T)\right)\right)$ of $G[S]$ with $P_{s}=U$ such that
(a) $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$;
(b) for every component $C$ of $G-S, N_{G}(V(C))$ intersects at most four components of $G-V(C)$;
(c) for every component $C$ of $G-S, N_{G}(V(C)) \subseteq P_{x} \cup P_{y}$ for some $x, y \in V(T)$ with either $x=y$ or $x y$ is an edge in $T$
(d) for every $x \in V(T)$,

$$
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G_{x}, P_{x}\right) \leqslant \bar{c}_{1}(t, Y) k \cdot r^{t-3} \log r
$$

for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$, where, for $T_{x}$ being the subtree of $T$ rooted in $x, G_{x}$ is the subgraph of $G$ induced by $U_{x}=\bigcup_{y \in V\left(T_{x}\right)} P_{y}$ and the vertex sets of all the components of $G-S$ having a neighbor in $U_{x}$.

Proof of the claim. Let $X^{\prime}=K_{1} \sqcup Y$. By Lemma 38 applied to $k=2$ and $X^{\prime}$, there exists a graph $X^{\prime \prime}$ with $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(X^{\prime \prime}\right)=\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(X^{\prime}\right)=t$ such that for every covering $S_{1}, S_{2}$ of $V\left(X^{\prime \prime}\right)$ there exists $i \in\{1,2\}$ such that $X^{\prime \prime}$ contains an $\left\{H \subseteq X^{\prime \prime} \mid H\right.$ connected and $\left.S_{i} \cap V(H) \neq \emptyset\right\}$-rich model of $X^{\prime}$. Let $\bar{c}_{1}(t, Y)=2+\bar{c}\left(t-1, X^{\prime \prime}\right)$.

We proceed by induction on $|V(G)|$. If $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{G-U}=\emptyset$, then since $\bar{c}_{1}(t, Y) \geqslant|U|$, the result holds. Now suppose that $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{G-U} \neq \emptyset$ and in particular, $|V(G)-U|>1$.

Let $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ be the family of all the connected subgraphs $H$ of $G-U$ such that $U \cap N_{G}(V(H)) \neq \emptyset$ and $F \subseteq H$ for some $F \in \mathcal{F}$. We argue that there is no $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$-rich model of $X^{\prime \prime}$ in $G-U$. Suppose to the contrary that there is an $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$-rich model $\left(B_{x} \mid x \in V\left(X^{\prime \prime}\right)\right)$ of $X^{\prime \prime}$ in $G-U$. For each $u \in U$, let $S_{u}=\left\{x \in V\left(X^{\prime \prime}\right) \mid u \in N_{G}\left(B_{x}\right)\right\}$. Since the model is $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$-rich, $\left\{S_{u}\right\}_{u \in U}$ is a covering of $V\left(X^{\prime \prime}\right)$. Therefore, there exists $u \in U$ such that $X^{\prime \prime}$ contains an $\left\{H \subseteq X^{\prime \prime} \mid\right.$ $H$ connected and $S_{u} \cap V(H) \neq \emptyset\}-$ rich model $\mathcal{M}$ of $X^{\prime}$. Moreover, by definition, each branch set of $\mathcal{M}$ contains a member of $\mathcal{F}$, and furthermore, $\mathcal{M}$ is a model of $X^{\prime}$ in $G$. Recall that $X^{\prime}=K_{1} \sqcup Y$. If $v$ is the vertex of $K_{1}$ is $X^{\prime}$, then the model obtained from $\mathcal{M}$ by replacing the branch set $C_{v}$ corresponding to $v$ by $C_{v} \cup\{u\}$ yields an $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $K_{1} \oplus Y$ in $G$, which is a contradiction. This proves that there is no $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$-rich model of $X^{\prime}$ in $G-\{u\}$.

Since $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(X^{\prime \prime}\right)=\operatorname{rtd}_{2}\left(X^{\prime}\right) \leqslant \max \left\{\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(Y), 1\right\} \leqslant t-1$, by the main induction hypothesis applied to $X^{\prime \prime}, G-U$, and $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ there exists a set $S_{0} \subseteq V(G-U)$ such that
(A') $V(F) \cap S_{0} \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}^{\prime}$;
(B') for every component $C$ of $(G-U)-S_{0}, N_{G-U}(V(C))$ intersects at most two components of $(G-U)-V(C)$;

$\left(\mathrm{C}^{\prime}\right) \operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G-U, S) \leqslant \bar{c}\left(t-1, X^{\prime \prime}\right) k \cdot r^{t-3} \log r$ for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$.
Note that $S_{0} \neq \emptyset$ since $\mathcal{F}^{\prime} \neq \emptyset$.
Let $\mathcal{C}_{1}$ be the family of all the components $C$ of $(G-U)-S_{0}$ such that $N_{G}(U) \cap V(C)=\emptyset$. Consider $C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$. Let $G_{C}$ be the graph obtained from $G\left[V(C) \cup N_{G}(V(C))\right]$ by contracting each component $C^{\prime}$ of $(G-U)-V(C)$ into a single vertex. Let $U_{C}$ be the set of all the vertices resulting from these contractions. Note that $U_{C}$ is not empty since $G$ is connected, and $\left|U_{C}\right| \leqslant 2$ by (B'). Since $N_{G}(U) \cap V(C)=\emptyset,\left|V\left(G_{C}\right)\right|<|V(G)|$. Since $G_{C}$ is a minor of $G, G_{C}$ has no $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{C^{-}}$rich model of $K_{1} \oplus Y$. By induction hypothesis applied to $G_{C}, u_{C}$, and $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{C}$, there exist $S_{C} \subseteq V\left(G_{C}\right)$, a tree $T_{C}$ rooted in $s_{C} \in V\left(T_{C}\right)$, and a tree partition $\left(T_{C},\left(P_{C, x} \mid x \in V\left(T_{C}\right)\right)\right.$ of $S_{C}$ in $G_{C}$ with $P_{C, s_{C}}=U$ such that
(a") $V(F) \cap S_{C} \neq \emptyset$ for every $\left.F \in \mathcal{F}\right|_{C}$
(b") for every component $C^{\prime}$ of $G_{C}-S_{C}, N_{G}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right)$ intersects at most four components of $G_{C}-V\left(C^{\prime}\right)$
(c") for every component $C^{\prime}$ of $G_{C}-S_{C}, N_{G_{C}}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right) \subseteq P_{C, x} \cup P_{C, y}$ for some $x, y \in V\left(T_{C}\right)$ and either $x=y$ or $x y$ is an edge in $T_{C}$;
(d") for every $x \in V\left(T_{C}\right)$,

$$
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G_{C, x}, P_{C, x}\right) \leqslant \bar{c}_{1}(t, Y) k \cdot r^{t-3} \log r
$$

for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$, where, for $T_{C, x}$ being the subtree of $T_{C}$ rooted in $x, G_{C, x}$ is the subgraph of $G_{C}$ induced by $U_{C, x}=\bigcup_{y \in V\left(T_{C, x}\right)} P_{C, y}$ and the vertex sets of all the components of $G_{C}-S_{C}$ having a neighbor in $U_{C, x}$.

Let

$$
S=U \cup S_{0} \cup \bigcup_{C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left(S_{C}-U_{C}\right)
$$

Let $T$ be obtained from the disjoint union of $\left\{T_{C} \mid C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}\right\}$ by identifying the vertices $\left\{s_{C} \mid C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}\right\}$ into a new vertex $s^{\prime}$ and by adding a new vertex $s$ adjacent to $s^{\prime}$ in $T$. Let $P_{s}=U, P_{s^{\prime}}=S_{0}$, and for each $C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}, x \in V\left(T_{C}-\left\{s_{C}\right\}\right)$, let $P_{x}=P_{C, x}$.

In order to conclude, we argue that $\left(T,\left(P_{x} \mid x \in V(T)\right)\right)$ is a tree partition of $G[S]$ and (a)-(d) hold.

Since for every $C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}, U \cap N_{G}(V(C))=\emptyset$, every edge in $G[S]$ containing a vertex in $U$ has another endpoint in $U \cup S_{0}=P_{s} \cup P_{s^{\prime}}$. Consider an edge $v w$ in $G[S]$ such that $v \in S_{0}$ and $w \in S_{C}$ for some $C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$. Since $\left(T_{C},\left(P_{C, x} \mid x \in V\left(T_{C}\right)\right)\right)$ is a tree partition of $G_{C}\left[S_{C}\right]$ with $P_{C, s_{C}}=U_{C}$ and $S_{0} \subseteq V((G-U)-V(C))$, we conclude that $w \in P_{x}$ for some $x \in V\left(T_{C}\right)$ such that $s^{\prime} x$ is an edge in $T$. Finally, for every edge $v w$ of $G[S]$ with $v, w \notin U \cup S_{0}, v w$ is an edge of $G\left[S_{C}-U_{C}\right]$ for some component $C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$, and so $v \in P_{C, x}$ and $w \in P_{C, y}$ for adjacent or identical vertices $x, y$ of $T_{C}$. Then $v \in P_{x}$ and $w \in P_{y}$. It follows that $\left(T,\left(P_{x} \mid x \in V(T)\right)\right)$ is a tree partition of $G[S]$.

Let $F \in \mathcal{F}$. If $V(F) \cap\left(U \cup S_{0}\right) \neq \emptyset$, then $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$. Otherwise, $F \subseteq G-U$ and $V(F) \cap S_{0}=\emptyset$, and therefore by (A'), $F \notin \mathcal{F}^{\prime}$, so in particular, $U \cap N_{G}(V(F))=\emptyset$. In this case, there is a component $C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ such that $F \in\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{C}$, thus, $V(F) \cap S_{C} \neq \emptyset$ by (a"). This proves (a).

Consider a component $C^{\prime}$ of $G-S$. If $C^{\prime} \subseteq C$ for some $C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$, then by (b"), it follows that $N_{G_{C}}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right)$ intersects at most four components of $G_{C}-V\left(C^{\prime}\right)$, and so $N_{G}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right)$ intersects at most four components of $G-V\left(C^{\prime}\right)$. Otherwise, $C^{\prime}$ is a component of $(G-U)-S_{0}$ such that $N_{G}(U) \cap V\left(C^{\prime}\right) \neq \emptyset$. By (B'), $N_{G-U}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right)$ intersects at most two components of

$(G-U)-V\left(C^{\prime}\right)$, and therefore, $N_{G}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right)$ intersects at most four components of $G-V\left(C^{\prime}\right)$. This proves (b).

For every component $C^{\prime}$ of $G-S$, either $N_{G}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right) \subseteq U \cup S_{0}=P_{s} \cup P_{s^{\prime}}$, or $C^{\prime} \subseteq C$ for some $C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$. In the latter case, $C^{\prime}$ is a component of $G_{C}-S_{C}$, and $N_{G}(U) \cap V(C)=\emptyset$. By (c"), there is $x, y \in V\left(T_{C}\right)$ such that $N_{G_{C}}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right) \subseteq P_{C, x} \cup P_{C, y}$, and thus, $N_{G}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right) \subseteq P_{x} \cup P_{y}$. This proves (c).

Finally, we argue (d). Let $r$ be an integer with $r \geqslant 2$ and let $x \in V(T)$. For $x=s$, $\left|P_{s}\right|=|U| \leqslant 2$, thus the assertion is clear. For $x=s^{\prime}$, we have that $G_{s^{\prime}}$ is a union of components of $G-U$. By (C'),

$$
\operatorname{wcol}\left(G_{s^{\prime}}, S_{0}\right)=\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G-U, S_{0}\right) \leqslant \bar{c}\left(t-1, X^{\prime \prime}\right) k \cdot r^{t-3} \log r \leqslant \bar{c}_{1}(t, Y) k \cdot r^{t-3} \log r
$$

For $x \in V\left(T_{C}-\left\{s_{C}\right\}\right)$ for some $C \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$, we have $G_{x}=G_{C, x}$, thus, the asserted inequality follows from ( $\left.\mathrm{d}^{\prime \prime}\right)$. This ends the proof of the claim.

Claim 4 yields the following less technical statement.
Claim 5. Let $Y$ be a graph with $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(Y) \leqslant t-1$. There are integers $\bar{c}_{2}(t, Y)$ such that for every positive integer $k$, for every graph $G$ with $\operatorname{tw}(G)<k$, for every family $\mathcal{F}$ of connected subgraphs of $G$, if $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $K_{1} \oplus Y$, then there exist $S \subseteq V(G)$ such that
(a) $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$;
(b) for every component $C$ of $G-S, N_{G}(V(C))$ intersects at most four components of $G-V(C)$;
(c) $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) \leqslant \bar{c}_{2}(t, Y) k \cdot r^{t-2} \log r$ for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$.

Proof of the claim. Let $\bar{c}_{2}(t, Y)=2 \cdot \bar{c}_{1}(t, Y)$ and let $r$ be an integer with $r \geqslant 2$. We apply Claim 4 with an arbitrary singleton $\{u\}$ in $G$ to obtain $S \subseteq V(G)$, a tree $T$ rooted in $s \in V(T)$, and a tree partition $\left(T,\left(P_{x} \mid x \in V(T)\right)\right.$ ) of $S$ in $G$ with $P_{s}=\{u\}$ such that
4.(a) $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$;
4.(b) for every component $C$ of $G-S, N_{G}(V(C))$ intersects at most four components of $G-V(C)$;
4.(c) for every component $C$ of $G-S, N_{G}(V(C)) \subseteq P_{x} \cup P_{y}$ for some $x, y \in V(T)$ with either $x=y$ or $x y$ is an edge in $T$;
4.(d) for every $x \in V(T)$,

$$
\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G_{x}, P_{x}\right) \leqslant \bar{c}_{1}(t, Y) k \cdot r^{t-3} \log r
$$

for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$, for $T_{x}$ being the subtree of $T$ rooted in $x, G_{x}$ is the subgraph of $G$ induced by $\bigcup_{y \in V\left(T_{x}\right)} P_{y}$ and the vertex sets of all the components of $G-S$ having a neighbor in $U_{x}$.

Items (a) and (b) hold by 4.(a) and 4.(b) respectively. It suffices to prove (c).
For each $x \in V(T)$, let $\sigma_{x}$ be an ordering of $P_{x}$ witnessing 4.(d) and let $\sigma^{\prime}=\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{|V(T)|}\right)$ be an elimination ordering of $T$. Finally, let $\sigma$ be the concatenation of $\sigma_{x_{1}}, \ldots, \sigma_{x_{|V(T)|}}$ in this order.

Let $u \in V(G)$. To conclude the claim, we argue that

$$
\left|\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u]\right| \leqslant \bar{c}_{2}(t, Y) k \cdot r^{t-1} \log r
$$

Let $x_{u} \in V(T)$ be such that if $u \in S$, then $u \in P_{x_{u}}$, and otherwise, $x_{u}$ is the vertex of $T$ furthest to $s$ such that $P_{x_{u}}$ intersects $N_{G}(V(C))$, where $C$ is the component of $u$ in $G-S$.

Let $A$ be the set of all the ancestors of $x_{u}$ in $T$ in distance at most $r$ from $x_{u}$. In particular, $|A| \leqslant r+1$. By Observation 19 and 4.(c),

$$
\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u] \subseteq \bigcup_{y \in A} P_{y}
$$

Let $y \in A$. Since $\sigma$ extends $\sigma_{y}$ and $x \in T_{y}$, by 4.(d), we have

$$
\left|\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u] \cap P_{y}\right| \leqslant \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G_{y}, P_{y}\right) \leqslant \bar{c}_{1}(t, X) k \cdot r^{t-2} \log r
$$

Summarizing,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u]\right| & =\sum_{y \in A}\left|\operatorname{WReach}_{r}[G, S, \sigma, u] \cap P_{y}\right| \\
& \leqslant(r+1) \cdot \bar{c}_{1}(t, X) k \cdot r^{t-2} \log r \\
& \leqslant 2 r \cdot \bar{c}_{1}(t, X) k \cdot r^{t-2} \log r=\bar{c}_{2}(t, Y) k \cdot r^{t-1} \log r
\end{aligned}
$$

This concludes the proof of (c), and the claim follows.
Claim 6. Let $Y$ be a graph with $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(Y) \leqslant t-1$ and let $h, d$ be positive integers. There exists an integer $\bar{c}_{3}(Y, h, d)$ such that for every positive integer $k$, for every graph $G$ with $\operatorname{tw}(G)<k$, for every family $\mathcal{F}$ of connected subgraphs of $G$, if $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $T_{h, d}^{\prime}(Y)$, then there exists $S \subseteq V(G)$ such that
(a) $V(F) \cap S \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$;
(b) for every component $C$ of $G-S, N_{G}(V(C))$ intersects at most $4 h$ components of $G-V(C)$;
(c) $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) \leqslant \bar{c}_{3}(Y, h, d) k \cdot r^{t-2} \log r$ for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$.

Proof of the claim. We proceed by induction on $h$. When $h=1, T_{h, d}^{\prime}(Y)=K_{1} \oplus(Y \sqcup Y)$ and the result follows from the previous claim applied to $Y \sqcup Y$ (note that $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(Y \sqcup Y)=\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(Y) \leqslant$ $t-1$ ) by setting $\bar{c}_{3}(Y, 1, d)=\bar{c}_{2}(t, Y \sqcup Y)$.

Now assume that $h>1$ and that the result holds for $h-1$. Fix a copy of $Y \sqcup Y$. For each $y \in V(Y \sqcup Y)$ add $d$ vertices with $y$ as a unique neighbor. Furthermore, add $2 d$ isolated vertices. We call the obtained graph $Z$ - see Figure 15. To keep things in order, we write $V(Z)=V_{Y} \cup V_{Z}$, where $V_{Y}$ are the vertices of $Y \sqcup Y$ in $Z$ and $V_{Z}$ are all the added vertices. Let

$$
\bar{c}_{3}(Y, h, d)=\bar{c}_{2}(t, Z)+\bar{c}_{3}(Y, h-1, d)
$$

By (r8) and (r4), $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(Z) \leqslant \max \left\{2, \operatorname{rtd}_{2}(Y)\right\} \leqslant t-1$ since $t \geqslant 3$.
Let $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ be the family of all the connected subgraphs $H$ of $G$ such that $H$ has an $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{H^{-}}$-rich model of $T_{h-1, d}^{\prime}(Y)$. We claim that there is no $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$-rich model of $K_{1} \oplus Z$ in $G$. Suppose to the contrary that such a model $\left(A_{y} \mid y \in V\left(K_{1} \oplus Z\right)\right)$ exists. Let $s$ be the vertex of $K_{1}$ in $K_{1} \oplus Z$. In particular, $V\left(K_{1} \oplus Z\right)=\{s\} \cup V_{Y} \cup V_{Z}$. For every vertex $z \in V_{Z}$, we define its parent in $K_{1} \oplus Z$ in the following way. Note that $z$ has at most one neighbor in $Z$. If $z$ has a neighbor in $Z$, then the neighbor is its parent and if $z$ is isolated in $Z$, then $s$ is its parent. Let $z \in V_{Z}$ with the parent $p_{z}$ and let $u_{z} \in A_{z}$ be such that there is an edge between $u_{z}$ and a vertex in $A_{p_{z}}$. Since the model is $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$-rich, $G\left[A_{z}\right]$ contains an $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{G\left[A_{z}\right]}$-rich model of $T_{h-1, d}^{\prime}(Y)$. Let $H_{z}$ be a copy of $T_{h-1, d}(Y)$ with a root $s_{z}$. By Lemma 29 applied to $Y, G\left[A_{z}\right]$, and $u$, there is an $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{G\left[A_{z}\right]}$-rich model $\left(B_{z, x} \mid x \in V\left(H_{z}\right)\right)$ of $H_{z}$ in $G\left[A_{z}\right]$ such that $u_{z} \in B_{z, s_{z}}$. In particular, there is an edge between $B_{z, s_{z}}$ and $A_{p_{z}}$ in $G$. Finally, we construct an $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $T_{h, d}^{\prime}(Y)$ in $G$. Observe that the graph obtained from $\left(K_{1} \oplus Z\right)\left[\{s\} \cup V_{Y}\right]$ (this graph is isomorphic to $\left.K_{1} \oplus(Y \sqcup Y)\right)$ and the disjoint union of $H_{z}$ for each $z \in V_{Z}$ by identifying $s_{z} \in V\left(H_{z}\right)$ with

$p_{z} \in\{s\} \cup V_{Y}$ for each $z \in V_{Z}$ is isomorphic to $T_{h, d}^{\prime}(Y)$. For each $p \in\{s\} \cup V_{Y}$, let $P_{y}$ be the set of all $z \in V_{Z}$ such that $p$ is the parent of $z$. Let
(i) $D_{p}=A_{p} \cup \bigcup_{z \in P_{p}} B_{z, s_{z}}$ for every $p \in\{s\} \cup V_{Y}$ and
(ii) $D_{x}=B_{z, x}$ for every $z \in V_{Z}$ and $x \in V\left(H_{z}-\left\{s_{z}\right\}\right)$.

It follows that $\left(D_{x} \mid x \in\{s\} \cup V_{Y} \cup \bigcup_{z \in V_{Z}} V\left(H_{z}-\left\{s_{z}\right\}\right)\right)$ is an $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $T_{h, d}^{\prime}(Y)$ in $G$. This is a contradiction, hence, $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$-rich model of $K_{1} \oplus Z$.

By Claim 5, applied to $Z, G$, and $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ there exists $S_{0} \subseteq V(G)$ such that
5.(a) $V(F) \cap S_{0} \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}^{\prime}$;
5.(b) for every component $C$ of $G-S_{0}, N_{G}(V(C))$ intersects at four components of $G-V(C)$;
5.(c) $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, S_{0}\right) \leqslant \bar{c}_{2}(t, 1, Z) k \cdot r^{t-2} \log r$ for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$.

Let $C$ be a component of $G-S_{0}$. Since $V(F) \cap S_{0} \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}^{\prime}, C$ has no $\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{C}$-rich model of $T_{h-1, d}^{\prime}(Y)$. Therefore, by induction hypothesis, there exists $S_{C} \subseteq V(C)$ such that
(a') $V(F) \cap S_{C} \neq \emptyset$ for every $\left.F \in \mathcal{F}\right|_{C}$
(b') for every component $C^{\prime}$ of $C-S, N_{C}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right)$ intersects at most $4(h-1)$ components of $C-V\left(C^{\prime}\right)$;
(c') $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(C, S_{C}\right) \leqslant \bar{c}_{3}(Y, h-1, d) k \cdot r^{t-2} \log r$ for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$.

Let $\mathcal{C}$ be the family of all the components of $G-S_{0}$ and let

$$
S=S_{0} \cup \bigcup_{C \in \mathcal{C}} S_{C}
$$

We claim that (a)-(c) hold. Let $F \in \mathcal{F}$. If $V(F) \cap S_{0}=\emptyset$, then $V(F) \subseteq V(C)$ for some component $C$ of $G-S_{0}$. In particular, $F \in\left.\mathcal{F}\right|_{C}$, and thus, by (a'), $V(F) \cap S_{C} \neq \emptyset$, which proves (a). Let $C$ be a component of $G-S$, and let $C^{\prime}$ be the component of $G-S_{0}$ intersecting $V(C)$. By (b'), $N_{C}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right)$ intersects at most $4(h-1)$ components of $C-V\left(C^{\prime}\right)$, and by 2.(b), $N_{G}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right)$ intersects at most fours components of $G-V\left(C^{\prime}\right)$. Hence, $N_{G}(V(C))$ intersects at most $4 h$ components of $G-V(C)$, which yields (b). The following sequence of inequalities concludes the proof of (c) and the claim:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) \leqslant \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, S_{0}\right)+\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G-S_{0}, \bigcup_{C \in \mathcal{C}} S_{C}\right) \quad \text { by Observation } 12 \\
& \leqslant \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, S_{0}\right)+\max _{C \in \mathcal{C}} \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(C, S_{C}\right) \quad \text { by Observation } 11 \\
& \leqslant \bar{c}_{2}(t, Z) k \cdot r^{t-2} \log r+\bar{c}_{3}(Y, h-1, d) k \cdot r^{t-2} \log r \quad \text { by 5.(c) and (c') } \\
& \leqslant\left(\bar{c}_{2}(t, Z)+\bar{c}_{3}(Y, h-1, d)\right) k \cdot r^{t-1} \log r \\
& =\bar{c}_{3}(Y, h, d) k \cdot r^{t-1} \log r
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, by Lemma 28, for every for every graph $X$ with $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(X) \leqslant t$, there exists a graph $Y$ with $\operatorname{rtd}_{2}(Y) \leqslant t-1$ and positive integers $h, d$ such that $X \subseteq T_{h, d}(Y) \subseteq T_{h, d}^{\prime}(Y)$. Let $G$ be a graph with $\operatorname{tw}(G)<k$ and let $\mathcal{F}$ be a family of connected subgraphs of $G$. Suppose that $G$ has no $\mathcal{F}$-rich model of $X$. By Claim 6, there exists $S_{0} \subseteq V(G)$ such that
6.(a) $V(F) \cap S_{0} \neq \emptyset$ for every $F \in \mathcal{F}$;
6.(b) for every component $C$ of $G-S_{0}, N_{G}(V(C))$ intersects at most $4 h$ components of $G-V(C)$;

6.(c) $\operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) \leqslant \bar{c}_{3}(Y, h, d) k \cdot r^{t-2} \log r$ for every integer $r$ with $r \geqslant 2$.

Let $\mathcal{C}$ be the family of components of $G-S_{0}$. Consider a component $C \in \mathcal{C}$. By 6.(b), $N_{G}(V(C))$ intersects at most $4 h$ components of $G-V(C)$. Let $C_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, C_{a}^{\prime}$ be the components of $G-V(C)$. For every $i \in[a-1]$, let $Q_{i}$ be a shortest $V\left(C_{i}^{\prime}\right)$ - $V\left(C_{i+1}^{\prime}\right)$ path in $G$. Now, let $\mathcal{Q}_{C}$ be the family $\left\{Q_{1}, \ldots, Q_{a-1}\right\}$. Note that for every component $C^{\prime}$ of $C-\bigcup_{Q \in \mathcal{Q}_{C}} V(Q)$, $N_{G}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right)$ intersects at most one component of $G-V\left(C^{\prime}\right)$.

Let

$$
S=S_{0} \cup \bigcup_{C \in \mathcal{C}} \bigcup_{Q \in \mathcal{Q}_{C}} V(Q)
$$

Item (A) follows from 6.(a). Let $C^{\prime}$ be a component of $G-S$, and let $C$ be the component of $G-$ $S_{0}$ intersecting $V\left(C^{\prime}\right)$. Then $N_{G}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right) \subseteq N_{G}(V(C)) \cup \bigcup_{Q \in \mathcal{Q}_{C}} V(Q)$, and since $\bigcup_{Q \in \mathcal{Q}_{C}} V(Q)$ induces a connected subgraph of $C$ and contains a neighbor of every component of $G-V(C)$ having a neighbor in $V(C)$, we deduce that $N_{G}\left(V\left(C^{\prime}\right)\right)$ intersects at most one component of $G-V\left(C^{\prime}\right)$. This proves that (B) holds. And finally, (C) is true once we set $\bar{c}(t, X)=$ $\bar{c}_{3}(Y, h, d)+(4 h-1) \cdot 3$ since

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{wcol}_{r}(G, S) \leqslant \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, S_{0}\right)+\operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G-S_{0}, \bigcup_{C \in \mathcal{C}} \bigcup_{Q \in \mathcal{Q}_{C}} V(Q)\right) \quad \text { by Observation } 12 \\
& \leqslant \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, S_{0}\right)+\max _{C \in \mathcal{C}} \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(C, \bigcup_{Q \in \mathcal{Q}_{C}} V(Q)\right) \quad \text { by Observation } 11 \\
& \leqslant \operatorname{wcol}_{r}\left(G, S_{0}\right)+\max _{C \in \mathcal{C}}\left|\mathcal{Q}_{C}\right|(2 r+1) \quad \text { by Observation } 13 \\
& \leqslant \bar{c}_{3}(Y, h, d) k \cdot r^{t-2} \log r+(4 h-1)(2 r+1) \quad \text { by 6.(c) } \\
& \leqslant\left(\bar{c}_{3}(Y, h, d)+(4 h-1) \cdot 3\right) k \cdot r^{t-2} \log r
\end{aligned}
$$

abstract:
We study the growth rate of weak coloring numbers of graphs excluding a fixed
graph as a minor. Van den Heuvel et al. (European J. of Combinatorics, 2017)
showed that for a fixed graph $X$, the maximum $r$-th weak coloring number of
$X$-minor-free graphs is polynomial in $r$. We determine this polynomial up to
a factor of $\mathcal{O}(r \log r)$. Moreover, we tie the exponent of the
polynomial to a structural property of $X$, namely, $2$-treedepth. As a result,
for a fixed graph $X$ and an $X$-minor-free graph $G$, we show that
$\mathrm{wcol}_r(G)= \mathcal{O}(r^{\mathrm{td}(X)-1}\mathrm{log}\ r)$, which
improves on the bound $\mathrm{wcol}_r(G) = \mathcal{O}(r^{g(\mathrm{td}(X))})$
given by Dujmovi\'c et al. (SODA, 2024), where $g$ is an exponential function.
In the case of planar graphs of bounded treewidth, we show that the maximum
$r$-th weak coloring number is in $\mathcal{O}(r^2\mathrm{log}\ r$), which is
best possible.
